PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Oxford, Mississippi. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1968 Code, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the board of aldermen. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1968 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been provided catchlines to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
    The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
    The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CHARTER CHT:1 RELATED LAWS RL:1 SPECIAL ACTS SA:1 CHARTER COMPARATIVE TABLE CHTCT:1 RELATED LAWS COMPARATIVE TABLE RLCT:1 SPECIAL ACTS COMPARATIVE TABLE SACT:1 CODE CD1:1 CODE APPENDIX CDA:1 CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES CCT:1 STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE SLT:1 CHARTER INDEX CHTi:1 CODE INDEX CDi:1  
Index 
    The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    This publication was under the direct supervision of Daniel Walker, Code Attorney, and Shelly Hayes, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publisher is most grateful to Ms. Lisa Carwyle, City Clerk, for her cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that her efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs.

ORDINANCE NO.__2008-3_______ 
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND ENACTING A NEW CODE FOR THE CITY OF OXFORD, MISSISSIPPI; PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN; PROVIDING A PENALTY FOR THE VIOLATION THEREOF; PROVIDING FOR THE MANNER OF AMENDING SUCH CODE; AND PROVIDING WHEN SUCH CODE AND THIS ORDINANCE SHALL BECOME EFFECTIVE. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE BOARD OF ALDERMEN: 
    Section 1. The Code entitled "Code of Ordinances of the City of Oxford, Mississippi," published by Municipal Code Corporation, consisting of chapters 1 through 118, each inclusive, is adopted. 
    Section 2. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before July 3, 2007, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are repealed. 
    Section 3. The repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance. 
    Section 4. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00, or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 90 days, and the cost of prosecution, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall continue or occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided, shall apply to the amendment of any Code section, whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the city may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief and revocation of licenses or permits. 
    Section 5. Additions or amendments to the Code, when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the city to make the same a part of the Code, shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
    Section 6. Ordinances adopted after July 3, 2007, which amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code, shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
    Section 7. This ordinance shall become effective April 2, 2008. 
The above ordinance having being first reduced to writing and read and considered section by section at a public meeting or the governing authorities of the City of Oxford Mississippi on motion of Alderman__Baker_____, seconded by Alderman__Antonow_______, and the roll being called, the same by the following votes:

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances of the City of Oxford, Mississippi," and may be so cited. 
(Code 1968, § 1-1) 
State Law reference- Authority to revise, codify and publish ordinances, MCA 1972, § 21-13-15. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and interpretation. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the mayor and board of aldermen: 
    Board, board of aldermen. Whenever the term "board" or "board of aldermen" is used in this Code, it means the Mayor and Board of Aldermen of the City of Oxford, Mississippi. 
    City. The terms "the city" or "this city" shall be construed as if the words "of Oxford, Mississippi" followed it. 
    Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day, and if the last day be Sunday or a legal holiday, that day shall be excluded. 
    Corporate limits, corporation limits, city limits. Whenever the term "corporate limits," "corporation limits," or "city limits" are used, they mean the legal boundary of the city. 
    County. Whenever the terms "the county" or "this county" are used, they mean the County of Lafayette, Mississippi. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring or authorizing the head of a department or agency of the city to do some act or make certain inspections, it shall be construed as authorizing the head of the department or agency to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the act or make the inspection unless the terms of the provision or section designate otherwise. 
    Gender. A term importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
    Interpretation. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provision imposed by the Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. 
    Joint authority. All terms giving a joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
    Keeper, proprietor. Whenever the term "keeper" or "proprietor" is used it means persons, firms, associations, corporations, clubs and partnerships, whether acting by themselves or through a servant, agent or employee. 
    Law. The term "law," when used in any ordinance, includes any provision of the Constitution of the United States, or the State of Mississippi, and any statute of the United States or the State of Mississippi, and any ordinance, resolution or order of the mayor and board of aldermen of Oxford, Mississippi. 
    MCA . The abbreviation "MCA" means the Mississippi Code Annotated, 1972. 
    Month. Whenever the term "month" is used it means a calendar month. 
    Name of officer. Whenever the name of an officer is given, it shall be construed as though the words "of the City of Oxford" followed it. 
    Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
    Number. Words used in the singular number only, either as descriptive of persons or things, shall extend to and embrace the plural number; and words used in the plural number shall extend to and embrace the singular number. 
    Oath. The term "oath" includes the term "affirmation," in all cases where by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath. 
    Offense. The term "offense" means any violation of an ordinance liable to punishment by criminal prosecution. 
    Or, and. "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or" if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. Whenever the term "owner" is applied to a building or land, it includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. Whenever the term "person" is used it shall include, mean and be applied to any natural individual, firm, partnership, association, joint stock company, joint adventure, public or private corporation, or to a receiver, executor, trustee, conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court or in any other manner. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" includes goods, chattels, effects, evidences of rights of action, and all written instruments by which any pecuniary obligation or any right, title or interest in any real or personal estate shall be created, acknowledged, transferred, incurred, defeated, discharged or diminished. 
    Preceding, following. Whenever the terms "preceding" and "following" are used they mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Premises. Whenever the term "premises" is used it means place or places. 
    Property. The term "property" includes personal property as defined herein and also every estate, interest or right in lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Real property. The term "real property" includes every estate, interest or right, in lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Residence. Whenever the term "residence" is used, it means the place adopted by a person as his place of habitation, and to which, whenever he is absent, he has the intention of returning. When a person eats at one place and sleeps at another, the place where such person sleeps shall be deemed his residence. 
    Seal. Whenever the term "seal" is used, it means the city or corporate seal. 
    Sidewalk. Whenever the term "sidewalk" is used it means any portion of a street between the curbline, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. 
    Signature or subscription. The term "signature" or "subscription" of a person includes a mark when the person cannot write. 
    State. Whenever the terms "the state" or "this state" are used they mean the State of Mississippi. 
    Street. Whenever the term "street" is used it means any street, avenue, boulevard, road, alley, lane, viaduct or other public highway in the city. 
    Sworn. The term "sworn" shall include the term "affirmed," in all cases where by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath. 
    Tenant, occupant. Whenever the term "tenant" or "occupant" is applied to a building or land, it includes any person holding a written or oral lease of, or who occupies the whole or a part of, such building or land, either alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Week. Whenever the term "week" is used, it means seven days. 
    Written, in writing . The terms "written" and "in writing" may include printing, engraving, lithographing or any other representation of words, letters or figures; except that in all cases where the signature of any person is required, it shall always be the proper handwriting or mark of such person. 
    Year. Whenever the term "year" is used, it means a calendar year. 
(Code 1968, § 1-2) 
State Law reference- For definitions of terms used in statutes, MCA 1972, § 1-3-3 et seq. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections including the catchlines, are amended or re-enacted. 
(Code 1968, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1968, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-5. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the mayor and board of aldermen that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality, invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1968, § 1-5) 
Sec. 1-6. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code, may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein. In the case of repeal of chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in substantially the following language: "That section _______ of the Code of Ordinances of the City, is hereby amended to read as follows:...." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as enacted. 
(c)  In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the Code of Ordinances of the City, is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered _______, which section reads as follows:...." The new section shall then be set out in full as enacted. 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed shall be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1968, § 1-6) 
State Law reference- Form of ordinances, MCA 1972, § 21-13-7. 
Sec. 1-7. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever, which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1968, § 1-7) 
Sec. 1-8. - General penalties, continuing violations; abatement of nuisances, continuing violations. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code, or in any ordinance of the city, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any ordinance shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 90 days, and the cost of prosecution, or by both such fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the municipal judge. Each day any violation of any provision of this Code or of any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  In addition to the penalties provided in subsection (a) of this section, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this Code or any ordinance shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be abated by the city, as provided by law; and each day that such condition continues shall be regarded as a new and separate offense. 
(Code 1968, § 1-8; Ord. of 4-7-1964, § 2; Ord. No. 1977-15, § 1, 11-1-1977) 
State Law reference- Authority to enforce ordinances by prescribing penalties, MCA 1972, § 21-13-1. 
Sec. 1-9. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-2, § I, adopted March 20, 2018, repealed § 1-9, which pertained to custody of prisoners and derived from the Code of 1968, § 1-10.

The land area described within this description contains 27.40 square miles, more or less. 
(c)  Improvements. The City of Oxford, Mississippi, shall make the following improvements in said annexed territory to be completed within a reasonable time, not to exceed five years from the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, unless delayed by war or military preparedness: 
(1)  Repair, replace or upgrade improved and in use streets to municipal standards as warranted by their age, condition and ability to accommodate traffic demands; 
(2)  Develop such new major streets as required by increased traffic demands to City standards in conformance with the city's comprehensive plan; 
(3)  Make intersection improvements, improve surface water drainage, install traffic control and safety devices, and install curbs, gutters, sidewalks, street signs, lighting and other related improvements to municipal standards where needed; 
(4)  Develop and improve storm-water drainage facilities consistent with applicable laws in a manner adequate to accommodate development to be protected; 
(5)  Construct and equip such additional public safety facilities as warranted by concentration of population and non-residential activities, proximity requirements and the operational realities of delivering public safety services; 
(6)  Develop additional parks, recreation and public assembly facilities based on an assessment of needs for such improvements and in conformance with the comprehensive plan and established city-wide standards for such improvements; and 
(7)  Acquire, upgrade and interconnect public water and sewer utility lines and extend new municipal utility services into developed areas annexed as necessary, where legally permissible and financially feasible. Provide adequate water pressure and volume for firefighting purposes in areas developed at sufficient density to be required consistent with standards established by the Mississippi State Rating Bureau. Municipal investment in new water and sewer infrastructure is to be determined through the feasibility of such development on a case by case basis. The extent of municipal financial commitment to utility system development is to be limited to securing of available federal and state grants and loans for new facilities, organizing special improvement districts to fund private components of such infrastructures, and use of capital improvement reserves and revenue bond issues for system-wide improvements which will enhance the utility system's financial viability. 
(d)  Services. The City of Oxford, Mississippi, shall furnish to the said annexed territory the following municipal and public services in the same manner and to the same extent as such services are being furnished to the present citizens of the municipality, such services to begin on the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, to wit: 
(1)  Police protection; 
(2)  Municipal court services; 
(3)  Animal control services; 
(4)  First response fire protection and fire prevention services; 
(5)  Emergency medical services; 
(6)  Emergency preparedness and civil defense services; 
(7)  Engineering services; 
(8)  Maintenance of streets and related structures; 
(9)  Right-of-way maintenance services; 
(10)  Traffic systems maintenance services; 
(11)  Storm-water drainage maintenance services; 
(12)  Street lighting; 
(13)  Administration of sanitation service; 
(14)  Access to the city's cultural facilities, services and programs; 
(15)  Access to the city's parks and recreation facilities and programs; 
(16)  Water and sewer utility services at in-city rates for those who are customers of the city utility services; 
(17)  Municipal planning and zoning services; 
(18)  Municipal code enforcement and building inspection services; 
(19)  The right to fully participate in the affairs of the municipality through direct involvement and the right to exercise the ballot (vote) in municipal elections upon registering and meeting all statutory and constitutional requirements; and 
(20)  The use and benefit of all other municipal services and facilities furnished to all present citizens of the City of Oxford, Mississippi. 
(Code 1968, § 1-11; Ord. of 5-17-1965, § 2; Ord. No. 1971-1, § 2, 4-6-1971; Ord. No. 1971-15, §§ 1, 2, 11-2-1971; Ord. No. 1975-4A, § 2, 6-3-1975; Ord. No. 1977-6, § 2, 3-1-1977; Ord. No. 1978-2, § 2, 2-21-1978; Ord. No. 1989-20, § 1, 12-5-1989; Ord. No. 1994-18, § 3, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 2000-2, § 2, 1-18-2000; Ord. No. 2006-14, § 1, 8-15-2006; Ord. No. 2013-15, §§ II-V, 9-3-2013; Ord. No. 2016-9, §§ II-V, 6-21-2016; Ord. No. 2018-3, §§ II-V, 4-3-2018) 
Sec. 1-11. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    At the time of adoption of this Code, nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance in effect: 
(1)  Promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by city; 
(2)  Containing any administrative provisions of the city board of aldermen not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this Code; 
(3)  Granting any right or franchise and establishing any rates therefor; 
(4)  Dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city; 
(5)  Making any appropriation; 
(6)  Levying or imposing taxes not inconsistent with this Code; 
(7)  Establishing or prescribing grades in the city; 
(8)  Providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor; 
(9)  Dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city; 
(10)  Adopting, extending or contracting the boundaries of the city; 
(11)  Prescribing the number, classification or compensation of any city officers or employees, not inconsistent with this Code; 
(12)  Prescribing traffic regulations for specific streets, or portions thereof, not inconsistent with this Code; 
(13)  Pertaining to rezoning of specific property; 
(14)  Any other ordinance, or part thereof, which is not of a general and permanent nature; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set forth in this Code, until revised or repealed after adoption of this Code. Such ordinances are on file in the city clerk's office. 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities generally, MCA 1972, § 21-1-1 et seq.; general municipal powers, MCA 1972, § 21-17-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Corporate name. 
    The corporate name of the city shall be "The City of Oxford," under which name the mayor and board of aldermen shall exercise and perform all the corporate powers, duties and obligations conferred or imposed on them or the members thereof. 
(Code 1968, § 2-1) 
Sec. 2-2. - Conflict of interest. 
(a)  Direct or indirect connection. It shall be unlawful for any officer or employee of the city to enter into or to have or to own any interest or share, individually or as agent or employee of any person or corporation, either directly or indirectly, in any contract made or let by the mayor and board of aldermen for the construction or doing of any public work, or for the sale or purchase of any materials, supplies, or property of any description, or for any other purpose whatsoever, or any subcontract arising therefrom or connected therewith, or to receive, either directly or indirectly, any portion or share of any money or other thing paid for the construction or doing of any public work, or the sale or purchase of any property, or upon any other contract made by the mayor and board of aldermen, or subcontract arising therefrom or connected therewith. 
(b)  Penalties. In addition to the penalties prescribed by law, any person violating the provisions of this section shall be removed from the office or employment then held by him, and shall not be eligible to succeed himself. However, nothing herein shall prohibit any bank from being selected as depository of the city for the reason that an officer or employee of the municipality is an officer or stockholder of such bank, when such bank has been selected as such municipal depository in the manner provided by law, and has duly qualified as such depository as required by law. 
(Code 1968, § 2-2) 
Secs. 2-3-2-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - THE MAYOR AND BOARD OF ALDERMAN[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Mayor and board of aldermen for code charter cities, MCA 1972, § 21-3-1 et seq.; qualifications of mayor and aldermen, MCA 1972, § 21-3-9. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-23. - Designation. 
    The governing body of the city shall be a mayor and board of aldermen, who shall be elected by the qualified voters of the city. 
(Code 1968, § 2-13) 
Sec. 2-24. - Officers and employees-Appointment. 
    The mayor and board of aldermen shall have the power to appoint a city tax assessor, tax collector, clerk, engineer, building inspector, light and water superintendent, gas and plumbing inspector, three municipal election commissioners, street commissioner and such other officers and employees as may be necessary for the conduct of city business. A member of the board of aldermen may be appointed to the office of street commissioner. 
(Code 1968, § 2-14) 
State Law reference- Appointive officers, MCA 1972, § 21-3-5. 
Sec. 2-25. - Same-Compensation. 
(a)  The compensation of all officers and employees of the city appointed by the mayor and board of aldermen shall be as prescribed by the mayor and board of aldermen from time to time. 
(b)  The annual salary of the mayor shall be $72,800.00, and the annual salary of each alderman shall be $14,000.00. However, effective July 1, 2017, the annual salary of the mayor shall be $85,000.00 and the annual salary of each alderman shall be $18,500.00. 
(c)  At least one year prior to the election of a new administration, the mayor and board of aldermen shall meet in open session to consider the appropriate level of construction for the next administration. During this discussion, the mayor and board shall take into consideration pay rate increases for other city employees, the consumer price index, compensation paid to elected officials in comparable communities, and any other factor the board and mayor consider pertinent. This subsection does not impose any obligation upon the board and mayor other than to review, at least once every four years, the level of compensation paid to elected officials. 
(Code 1968, § 2-15; Ord. No. 1993-2, § 1, 2-2-1993; Ord. No. 1997-3, § 1, 2-18-1997; Ord. No. 2003-26, § I, 12-12-2003; Ord. No. 2008-7, § I, 6-17-2008; Ord. No. 2016-14, § I, 10-4-2016) 
Sec. 2-26. - Same-Length of service. 
    All officers and employees of the city appointed by the mayor and board of aldermen shall hold office or employment at the pleasure of the mayor and board of aldermen and may be discharged by the same at any time, either with or without cause. 
(Code 1968, § 2-16) 
Sec. 2-27. - Same-Bonds. 
    No officer or employee of the city, or any other person acting in behalf of the city shall be authorized to receive funds due the city or to give any receipts therefor, other than authorized personnel. All city officers and employees handling or having access to municipal funds, shall be bonded in an amount not less than the minimum required by state law, and as established from time to time by the board of aldermen. The premiums due on bonds required under the provision of this section shall be paid out of municipal funds. 
(Code 1968, § 2-17) 
Sec. 2-28. - Multiple offices may be held by one appointee. 
    The mayor and board of aldermen shall have the power and authority to appoint the same person to any two or more appointive offices. 
(Code 1968, § 2-18) 
Sec. 2-29. - Commissions and appointments. 
    The mayor shall sign the commissions and appointments of all officers elected and appointed by the mayor and board of aldermen and such commissions and appointments shall be attested by the clerk; provided however, the refusal, failure or neglect of the mayor to sign such commissions and appointments, or the refusal, failure or neglect of the clerk to attest the same, shall not affect the validity of the acts of such officer or appointee when the minutes show the election appointment was regularly made by the board. 
(Code 1968, § 2-19) 
State Law reference- Signing of commissions and appointments, MCA 1972, § 21-3-17. 
Secs. 2-30-2-46. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MAYOR 

Sec. 2-47. - Generally. 
    The mayor shall have the superintending control of all the officers, employees and affairs of the city and shall take care that the laws and ordinances of the city are enforced and executed. 
(Code 1968, § 2-25) 
Sec. 2-48. - Presiding officer at meetings. 
    The mayor shall preside at all meetings of the board of aldermen. 
(Code 1968, § 2-26) 
Sec. 2-49. - Deciding vote. 
    In the event there shall be an equal division or vote by the board of aldermen, the mayor shall give the deciding vote. 
(Code 1968, § 2-27) 
Sec. 2-50. - Power of veto. 
    The mayor shall have the power to veto any measure passed by the board of aldermen, in writing, giving his reasons therefor; provided however, any such measure so vetoed may be adopted notwithstanding such veto by a two-thirds vote of the aldermen therefor. 
(Code 1968, § 2-28) 
State Law reference- Mayoral veto, override by board, MCA 1972, § 21-3-15. 
Sec. 2-51. - Act as police justice. 
    The mayor shall be the police justice of the city and shall exercise all the powers and discharge all the duties thereof provided by state law. 
(Code 1968, § 2-29) 
Sec. 2-52. - Mayor pro tempore. 
    The board of aldermen shall elect from among its members a mayor pro tempore. 
(Code 1968, § 2-30) 
State Law reference- Mayor pro tempore, MCA 1972, § 21-3-13. 
Secs. 2-53-2-77. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BOARD OF ALDERMEN[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Number of aldermen and their election, MCA 1972, § 21-3-7; qualifications of mayor and aldermen, MCA 1972, § 21-3-9. 

Sec. 2-78. - Number. 
    The board of aldermen of the city shall be composed of seven members. 
(Code 1968, § 2-36; Ord. No. 1972-22, § 1, 12-5-1972; Ord. No. 1976-10, § 1, 9-7-1976; Ord. No. 1992-5, § 1, 6-2-1992) 
Sec. 2-79. - Manner of election. 
(a)  The aldermen of the city shall be elected in the following manner: 
(1)  Six aldermen shall be elected according to their respective wards; and 
(2)  One aldermen shall be elected at-large. 
(b)  Such election is to be held at the regularly scheduled time for election of municipal officers and in accordance with the applicable laws. 
(Code 1968, § 2-37; Ord. No. 1972-22, § 2, 12-5-1972; Ord. No. 1976-10, § 2, 9-7-1976; Ord. No. 1992-5, § 2, 6-2-1992) 
Sec. 2-80. - Duties and qualifications generally. 
    The duties and qualifications of the members of the board of aldermen shall be those prescribed by state law, the provisions of this Code and city ordinances. 
(Code 1968, § 2-38) 
Sec. 2-81. - Quorum. 
    A majority of the members of the board of aldermen shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Code 1968, § 2-39) 
Sec. 2-82. - Regular meetings. 
    The mayor and board of aldermen shall hold regular meetings on the first and third Tuesday of each month at the city hall, in the boardroom, at 5:00 p.m. When a regular meeting of the mayor and board of aldermen shall fall upon a holiday, the mayor and board shall meet the following day at the same place and time. The mayor and board may recess either meeting from time to time to convene on a day fixed by an order of the mayor and board, entered on its minutes, and may transact any business coming before it for consideration. In all cases it shall require a majority of all aldermen to constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. Any board member may participate in an official meeting of the board by teleconference or video means in the manner allowed by law. This ordinance shall serve as notice to the public that any board member may participate in a regularly-scheduled meeting of the board by teleconference or video means. Any board member may participate in any other meeting of the board by teleconference of video means pursuant to the requirements of the Mississippi Open Meetings Act, MCA 1972, § 25-41-1 et seq., or as such statute may be amended. 
(Code 1968, § 2-40; Ord. No. 1977-12, § 1, 9-6-1977; Ord. No. 1991-20, § 1, 12-3-1991; Ord. No. 1992-8, § 1, 7-7-1992; Ord. No. 1997-9, § 1, 8-19-1997; Ord. No. 2013-10, 7-23-2013; Ord. No. 2014-6, 3-4-2014) 
State Law reference- Regular meetings of board of aldermen, recess of meeting, MCA 1972, § 21-3-19. 
Sec. 2-83. - Special meetings. 
    The mayor or any two aldermen may, by written notice, call a special meeting of the mayor and board of aldermen for the transaction of important business. 
(Code 1968, § 2-41) 
State Law reference- Special meetings, MCA 1972, § 21-3-21. 
Secs. 2-84-2-109. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CITY PLANNING COMMISSION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Creation and powers of planning commission, MCA 1972, § 17-1-11. 

Sec. 2-110. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commission means the planning commission of the city. 
(Code 1968, § 2-52; Ord. of 3-1-1966, § 1) 
Sec. 2-111. - Created. 
    A commission, to be known as the Oxford Planning Commission, is hereby created in and for the city. 
(Code 1968, § 2-53; Ord. of 3-1-1966, § 1) 
Sec. 2-112. - Purpose. 
    The commission is created in order that adequate provision shall be made for the preparation and control of the development of the city and contiguous territory beyond the city limits not included in any municipality. 
(Code 1968, § 2-54; Ord. of 3-1-1966, § 1) 
Sec. 2-113. - Composition. 
    The commission shall consist of seven regular voting members, appointed by the mayor with the approval of the board of aldermen. 
(Code 1968, § 2-55; Ord. of 3-1-1966, § 2; Ord. No. 1976-4, § 1, 4-6-1976; Ord. No. 1989-10, § 1, 7-5-1989; Ord. No. 1997-7, § 1, 7-10-1997) 
Sec. 2-114. - Advisory members. 
    The city engineer and the city director of planning and development shall serve as advisory nonvoting member of the commission. 
(Code 1968, § 2-57; Ord. of 3-1-1966, § 2; Ord. No. 1976-4, § 3, 4-6-1976; Ord. No. 1997-7, § 2, 7-10-1997; Ord. No. 1998-27, § 1, 11-17-1998) 
Sec. 2-115. - Terms. 
    Four members of the commission shall be appointed to a four-year term to begin concurrently with the term of the office of the mayor. The remaining three members of the commission shall be appointed to a four-year term to begin on July 1, two years following the appointment of the other four members. All members serve at the will and pleasure of the governing authority of the City of Oxford. 
(Code 1968, § 2-58; Ord. of 3-1-1966, § 2; Ord. No. 2008-5, § V, 5-20-2008) 
Sec. 2-116. - Filling of vacancies. 
    Vacancies which may occur in the membership of the commission shall be filled by appointment of the mayor with the approval of the board of aldermen for the unexpired term only. Any member who misses three regular scheduled meetings during a year from July 1 through June 30 shall be deemed to have vacated their office. 
(Code 1968, § 2-59; Ord. of 3-1-1966, § 2; Ord. No. 1997-7, § 3, 7-10-1997; Ord. No. 1998-10, § 1, 5-5-1998; Ord. No. 2000-11, § 1, 5-16-2000) 
Sec. 2-117. - Compensation. 
    Members of the commission may be compensated as authorized by the mayor and board of aldermen and may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with the performance of their duties. 
(Code 1968, § 2-60; Ord. of 3-1-1966, § 2; Ord. No. 1989-10, § 2, 7-5-1989) 
Sec. 2-118. - Chairman. 
    Every year on July 1, the mayor shall designate one member of the commission to serve as its chairman. 
(Code 1968, § 2-61; Ord. of 3-1-1966, § 2; Ord. No. 2008-5, § V, 5-20-2008) 
Sec. 2-119. - Secretary. 
    The commission shall appoint a secretary who may be an officer or employee of the city or the county. 
(Code 1968, § 2-62; Ord. of 3-1-1966, § 3) 
Sec. 2-120. - Rules of procedure. 
    The commission shall make its own rules for procedure for the conduct of its meetings. 
(Code 1968, § 2-63; Ord. of 3-1-1966, § 3) 
Sec. 2-121. - Meetings generally. 
    The commission shall meet at such times and places as it shall designate from time to time. 
(Code 1968, § 2-64; Ord. of 3-1-1966, § 3) 
Sec. 2-122. - Publicity of meetings, records. 
    It shall be required of the commission to open its meetings to the public as required by law. 
(Code 1968, § 2-65; Ord. of 3-1-1966, § 3; Ord. No. 1989-10, § 3, 7-5-1989) 
Sec. 2-123. - Employment of personnel. 
    The commission may appoint or employ such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work. 
(Code 1968, § 2-66; Ord. of 3-1-1966, § 3) 
Sec. 2-124. - Expenditures generally. 
    The salaries and wages of the commission's staff and employees and its other necessary expenses shall be provided for by adequate appropriation made by the board of aldermen from the general fund. The commission may cooperate with, contract with, and receive funds from federal, state or local agencies or private individuals or corporations and may expend such funds and carry out such cooperative undertakings and contracts. The expenditures of the commission, exclusive of gifts and grants, shall be within the amounts appropriated for that purpose by the board of aldermen. 
(Code 1968, § 2-67; Ord. of 3-1-1966, § 3) 
Sec. 2-125. - Powers and duties generally. 
    The commission shall have, in addition to the powers, duties and responsibilities set forth in state law, the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To prepare and recommend to the board of aldermen a comprehensive plan for the present and future development of the city and contiguous unincorporated territory beyond the corporate limits of the city not included in any other community, pursuant to the provisions of state law. Such plans may be adopted in whole or in separate geographical or functional parts, each of which, when adopted, shall be the official comprehensive plan, or part thereof, of the city. Such plan shall be advisory, except as to such part thereof as has been implemented by ordinances duly enacted by the board of aldermen. 
(2)  To designate land suitable for annexation to the municipality and the recommended zoning classification for such land upon annexation. 
(3)  To recommend to the board of aldermen from time to time, such changes in the official comprehensive plan or any part thereof as may be deemed necessary. 
(4)  To prepare and recommend to the board of aldermen from time to time, plans and/or recommendations for specific improvements in pursuance of the official comprehensive plan. 
(5)  To give aid to the officials of the city, charged with the directions of projects for improvements embraced within the official comprehensive plan or parts thereof, to further the making of such improvements, and generally to promote the realization of the official comprehensive plan. 
(6)  To arrange and conduct any form of publicity relative to its activities for the general purpose of public understanding. 
(7)  To cooperate with municipal or regional planning commissions and other agencies or groups to further the local planning program and to assure harmonious and integrated planning for the area. 
(8)  The city planning commission shall also serve as the board of adjustment specified in the Code of the city, and as the board of adjustments and appeals specified in the city building code, as the same may from time to time be amended, revised, or updated. 
(Code 1968, § 2-68; Ord. of 3-1-1966, § 4; Ord. No. 1982-33, § 2, 11-2-1982) 
Sec. 2-126. - Copies of public improvements. 
    The city clerk shall furnish to the commission for its consideration a copy of all ordinances, plans and data relative to public improvements of any nature for the city. The commission may report in relation thereto if it deems a report necessary or advisable for the consideration of the board of aldermen. 
(Code 1968, § 2-69; Ord. of 3-1-1966, § 5) 
Secs. 2-127-2-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SCHOOL BOARD OF TRUSTEES 

Sec. 2-151. - Composition. 
    The board of trustees for the Oxford Municipal Separate School District shall consist of five members. 
(Code 1968, § 2-80) 
Sec. 2-152. - Election of trustees. 
(a)  By November 1 of each year, the city municipal school district shall furnish the city with the total number of students enrolled in the school district and the number of students enrolled in the district who reside outside of the corporate limits of the city. Should there be any question as to whether a student resides inside or outside the corporate limits of the city, city personnel shall assist school personnel in making that determination. 
(b)  In the event the territory of the school district located outside of the corporate limits of the city furnishes less than 30 percent of the pupils enrolled in the school district, then one member of the board of trustees shall be a resident of the added territory outside the corporate limits and shall be elected by the qualified electors of the school district residing outside the corporate limits of the city but within the school district. 
(c)  In the event the territory of the school district located outside of the corporate limits of the city furnishes 30 percent or more of the pupils enrolled in the school district, then two members of the board of trustees shall be residents of the added territory outside the corporate limits and shall be elected by the qualified electors of the school district residing outside the corporate limits of the city but within the school district. 
(d)  Any time there is only one elected member of the board of trustees and, by the preceding November 1 it is determined that 30 percent or more of the students attending the district are from the area outside of the corporate limits of the city, then the position which expires the following spring, if currently an appointed position, shall be changed to an elected position and shall be an individual residing in the school district but outside of the corporate limits of the city. If the position expiring in the spring is already an elected position, it shall remain an elected position. In this case, as there will continue to be only one elected individual to the board of trustees, a determination must be made again by the following November 1 as to whether the number of students attending the school district from outside the corporate limits is still equal to or greater than 30 percent of the total number of students, and, in this case, the appointed position expiring the following spring shall change to an elected position and shall be an individual residing inside the school district but outside of the corporate limits of the city. However, if by the following November 1 the number of student residing outside the corporate limits has dropped below 30 percent of the total number of students, then the appointed position expiring the following spring shall remain an appointed position and shall be an individual residing inside the corporate limits. 
(e)  Any time there are two elected members of the board of trustees and, by the preceding November 1 it is determined that less than 30 percent of the students attending the district are from the area outside of the corporate limits of the city, then the position which expires the following spring, if currently an elected position, shall be changed to an appointed position and shall be an individual residing inside the corporate limits of the city. If the position expiring in the spring is already an appointed position, it shall remain an appointed position. In this case, as there will continue to be two elected individuals to the board of trustees, a determination must be made again by the following November 1 as to whether the number of students attending the school district from outside the corporate limits is still less than 30 percent of the total number of students, and, in this case, if the position expiring the following spring is an elected position, it shall change to an appointed position and shall be an individual residing inside the corporate limits of the city. However, if by the following November 1 the number of students residing outside the corporate limits has again reached or exceeded 30 percent of the total number of students, then the elected position expiring the following spring shall remain an elected position and shall be an individual residing inside the corporate limits. 
(f)  The remaining members of the board of trustees shall reside inside the corporate limits of the city and within the school district, and shall be appointed by the mayor and the board of aldermen. 
(g)  All vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired terms by appointment of the governing authorities of the municipality. In the case of trustees coming from the school district area outside of the corporate limits of the city, the person so appointed shall reside in the school district area outside of the corporate limits of the city and shall serve only until the first Saturday of March following his appointment, at which time a person shall be elected for the remainder of the unexpired term in the manner otherwise provided herein. 
(Code 1968, § 2-81; Ord. No. 2003-18, § I, 10-21-2003) 
Sec. 2-153. - Terms. 
    The members of the board of trustees for the school district shall serve for terms of five years. The election and appointment of the members of the board of trustees shall be made in such a manner as to cause such terms to be staggered with one member's term commencing each year. 
(Code 1968, § 2-82) 
Sec. 2-154. - Powers and duties. 
    The powers and duties of the board of trustees of the school district shall be as prescribed by law. 
(Code 1968, § 2-83) 
Secs. 2-155-2-176. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - EMPLOYEE BENEFITS

Sec. 2-206. - Coverage extended.

In pursuance of said policy, and for that purpose, the officers shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations.

ARTICLE VI. - MAYOR'S COMMISSION ON DISABILITY ISSUES 

Sec. 2-210. - Title. 
    There is hereby established a new article entitled "mayor's commission on disability issues" under article VI of the City of Oxford, Mississippi Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 2011-4, 4-19-2011) 
Sec. 2-211. - Full participation. 
    The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), enacted on July 26, 1990 as amended, provides comprehensive rights and protections to individuals with disabilities in the areas of employment, public accommodations, state and local government services, and telecommunications. The goal of the ADA is to assure equality of opportunity, full participation, independent living and economic self-sufficiency. The ADA prohibits all state and local governments and most private businesses from discriminating on the basis of disability. The city board of aldermen finds that to assist in assuring compliance and to work toward full participation by persons with disabilities, it is appropriate to consult with persons with disabilities as to what will work best to provide for full participation for all persons. 
(Ord. No. 2011-4, 4-19-2011) 
Sec. 2-212. - Mayor's commission on disability issues. 
(a)  Composition of the commission. There is hereby instituted a commission of persons with disabilities and others who work to promote full participation by persons with disabilities to review city programs for accessibility which shall consist of seven to nine members, the majority of which will have disabilities. The members shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city's board of aldermen. This commission is organized to increase awareness of disability issues and to help promote equality for those with disabilities in matters of access in housing, public facilities, transportation and other areas as needed to help increase the quality of life for citizens with disabilities in the city. 
    The commission members shall elect from among themselves a chairperson, vice-chairperson and a secretary for a three-year period. Ex-officio members include the mayor, designated city department heads, a member of the board of aldermen, and others as deemed appropriate. All members shall be appointed by the mayor. Members shall serve at the will and pleasure of the mayor. 
(b)  Rules of procedure. The rules in the current edition of "Robert's Rules of Order Newly Revised" shall govern the commission in all cases to which they are applicable and in which they are not inconsistent with these bylaws and any special rules of order the commission may adopt. Motions before the commission are decided by a majority vote. In the event of a tie, the mayor will cast the deciding vote. In the mayor's absence, the alderman will cast the deciding vote. 
(c)  Meeting times. The commission shall set a regular meeting time at least six times per year. The time and place for regularly scheduled meetings shall be decided upon at the October meeting each year. Special meetings can be called by the chairperson or three members of the commission with five days written notice. 
(d)  Quorum. A quorum shall consist of a majority of the members of the commission who are duly appointed and qualified. 
(e)  Duties of officers. The officers of the commission shall consist of a chairperson, vice-chairperson, and secretary. Officers shall be elected by the commission at the October meeting of the commission. 
(1)  Chairperson. The chairperson shall preside at all meetings of the commission and perform all duties incident to this office. 
(2)  Vice-chairperson. The vice-chairperson shall act in the absence of the chairperson. 
(3)  Secretary. The secretary shall cause to be recorded the minutes agenda and minutes for each meeting and preparation of other documents as needed. 
(Ord. No. 2011-4, 4-19-2011; Ord. No. 2016-5, 2-16-2016) 
Sec. 2-213. - Tasks. 
(a)  Review programs. The Commission shall meet regularly with the ADA coordinator to review employment practices, the various programs and facilities of the city to assist with developing compliance with state and federal laws and to assist in improving accessibility by persons with disabilities to employment, programs and facilities. 
(b)  Provide recommendations. The commission shall have the authority to recommend to the city actions required to correct areas of non-compliance and inaccessibility. These actions may include recommending handicapped parking spaces and the withholding of a certificate of occupancy as a consequence for non-compliance. 
(c)  Report. The commission shall make a yearly report to the board of aldermen on its activities and accessibility issues within the city. 
(d)  Other assignments. The mayor may refer such other items to the commission for review such as issues of accommodation for employees with disabilities. 
(Ord. No. 2011-4, 4-19-2011) 
Secs. 2-214-2-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - DOWNTOWN PARKING ADVISORY COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-221. - Mission statement. 
    That the downtown parking advisory commission be established to study, make recommendations and advise the city's governing authorities on the management of downtown parking resources, parking alternatives, and amenities within the downtown parking district (map attached*). The downtown parking advisory commission promotes public trust through program transparency, identifies solution options through community outreach and monitors results and feedback to respond to changing conditions. 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 1, 11-1-2011) 
Editor's note- Map was not included for codification of this article. 
Sec. 2-222. - Guiding principals. 
(a)  Prioritizes the customer/client/visitor as the desired on-street parker. 
(b)  Ensures a 15 percent vacancy of on-street parking spaces (one in six spaces open per block). 
(c)  Creates a parking system that is easy to understand for visitors and others new to the system. 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 2, 11-1-2011) 
Sec. 2-223. - Duties of the commission. 
    The downtown parking advisory commission will include but not be limited to making recommendations to the board of aldermen concerning the following: 
(1)  Installation, leasing, construction, maintenance, management, marketing, operation, repair, acquisition, financing and control of new and existing public parking resources. 
(2)  Planning, design, and location of parking facilities and structures. 
(3)  Hiring qualified personnel, firms and corporations to construct, operate and/or manage any public parking resource or facility. 
(4)  Setting of rates, charges and policies for parking on-street, off-street, and parking facilities. 
(5)  Development of a long term strategy for managing existing and future parking demands and resources. 
(6)  Estimating revenues and potential budgetary requirements related to the development, management, and maintenance of public parking resources and facilities and suggesting any required changes to such revenues and budgetary requirements for consideration of and action on such issues by the governing authorities for the city. 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 3, 11-1-2011) 
Sec. 2-224. - Downtown parking special revenue fund. 
    The downtown parking special revenue fund shall be a fund separate from the city's general fund and utilized by the downtown parking advisory commission, with the consent of the board of aldermen, to carry out both the mission and the duties described under this article. The fund shall be comprised of revenues received by the city for parking fees, parking fines, and other fees for parking permits. The board of aldermen shall have authority to determine what portion of such fees and fines shall be dedicated to the downtown parking special revenue fund, and shall be further empowered to dedicate additional funding to the downtown parking special revenue fund, in its sole discretion. 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 4, 11-1-2011) 
Sec. 2-225. - Composition and terms. 
    The downtown parking advisory commission shall consist of nine members appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the board of aldermen. The membership shall be comprised of two representatives from the downtown merchants, five representatives from the city at-large, one representative from Lafayette County who may or may not reside in the city, and one representative from one of the churches located downtown that has significant parking available, and that could therefore be particularly affected by parking policies and decisions in the downtown area. 
    Each member of the commission shall serve a term of three years; provided however, the terms of the initial commission shall be staggered such that three of the commissioners first appointed shall be designated to serve terms of one year, three of the commissioners first appointed shall be designated to serve terms of two years, and the remaining three members first appointed shall be designated to serve terms of three years. A commissioner shall hold office until his or her successor has been appointed. Vacancies shall be filled for any unexpired term in the manner prescribed for in the original appointment. 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 5, 11-1-2011) 
Secs. 2-226-2-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - HISTORIC PROPERTIES COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-231. - Mission statement. 
    That the historic properties commission be established to study, make recommendations and advise the city's governing authorities on the management, maintenance, marketing, and long-range preservation of the city's historic homes and/or properties. The historic properties commission shall further promote the public trust through program transparency, and shall identify solutions through community outreach and involvement in its decision-making process. 
(Ord. No. 2013-11, § 1, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 2-232. - Guiding principals. 
    The historic properties commission shall endeavor to perform the following functions on an ongoing basis: 
(1)  Prioritize the maintenance, repair, and preservation work which should be done to insure viability of the properties within the city's inventory of historic homes and properties for the use and enjoyment of the public now, and in the future; 
(2)  Consider and formulate plans for the use and enjoyment of such properties now, and in the future; 
(3)  Recommend marketing, grant, and outreach programs for such properties so that the properties may generate money or other forms of assistance that will allow them to be maintained and used efficiently now, and in the future. 
(Ord. No. 2013-11, § 2, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 2-233. - The duties of the commission. 
    The duties of the historic properties commission will include but not be limited to making recommendations to the board of aldermen concerning the following: 
(1)  To ensure that the historic properties placed under purview are properly maintained, utilized and marketed in a manner that maximizes their intended use by the citizens of Oxford and enhances Oxford tourism. 
(2)  To set the operational schedules, guidelines for use and admission/use fees. 
(3)  To develop an annual budget for each property, and to recommend approval of such budget annually to the board of aldermen. The recommended budget shall be submitted to the board of aldermen each year for consideration by July 1. 
(4)  To approve and track all expenditures against the approved budget, and review the previous year's result with the board of aldermen, at the same time the commission presents its recommended budget. 
(5)  To develop and coordinate a marketing plan for each property. 
(6)  To coordinate with each properties' "friends group" for volunteers in staffing and any financial support they provide. 
(7)  To development of a long term strategy for managing and preserving the city's historic properties, and to generate funds to assist in such management and preservation. 
(Ord. No. 2013-11, § 3, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 2-234. - Board of alderman review. 
    The board of aldermen shall review the budget as recommended by the historic properties commission on an annual basis. At the time such review is conducted, the board of aldermen shall also review the overall inventory of properties, excluding any assets loaned by others. The board's review shall include an assessment of the continued economic, cultural, industrial, historic, social and tourism value of the properties managed and/or overseen by the commission, and the continued viability of the maintenance, ownership, and operation of such properties by the City of Oxford. This provision is not intended to limit such consideration by the board of aldermen at any other time it may choose to do so. 
(Ord. No. 2013-11, § 4, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 2-235. - Historic properties special revenue fund. 
    The historic properties special revenue reserve fund shall be a fund which the board of aldermen shall establish, in which the city shall set aside funds in the budget for capital expenditures for the historic homes or properties covered hereunder. The historic properties commission shall make recommendations to the board of aldermen for disbursements of such funds so that the commission may carry out its mission and the duties described in this article. The fund shall be comprised of revenues received by the City of Oxford for preservation of historic properties. The board of aldermen shall have authority to determine what portion of such revenues shall be dedicated to the historic properties special revenue fund, and shall be further empowered to dedicate additional funding to the historic properties special revenue fund, in its sole discretion. 
(Ord. No. 2013-11, § 5, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 2-236. - Composition and terms. 
    The historic properties commission shall consist of a chairman appointed by the mayor for a four-year term and six commissioners recommended by the mayor and approved by the board of aldermen for two-year terms. The membership shall be comprised as follows: One representative shall be nominated from the Cedar Oaks Guild, one representative shall be nominated from Friends of Lamar House, one representative shall be nominated from the Burns Belfry Advisory Board (friends group) and three representatives shall be members at large. This will become effective with the transfer of the Burns Belfry to the City of Oxford. 
    Each member of the commission shall serve a term of two years; provided however, the terms of the initial commission shall be staggered such that three of the commissioners first appointed shall be designated to serve terms of one year, and three of the commissioners first appointed shall be designated to serve terms of two years. The chairman shall serve a term of four years. A commissioner shall hold office until his or her successor has been appointed. Vacancies shall be filled for any unexpired term in the manner prescribed for the original appointment. 
(Ord. No. 2013-11, § 6, 8-6-2013; Ord. No. 2015-23, 8-18-2015) 
Chapter 6 - ADVERTISING 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Posting of signs, posters prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or place any sign, poster or other advertisement upon public street rights-of-way or any publicly owned property or upon any light pole, telephone pole or tree situated upon such property without first having obtained the consent thereof of the mayor and board of aldermen. Any such sign, poster or other advertisement illegally placed upon such property shall be removed and impounded by the city. 
(Code 1968, § 3-1; Ord. of 7-2-1963, § 1; Ord. No. 1998-7, § 1, 4-7-1998) 
Sec. 6-2. - Impoundment of signs. 
    Any sign, poster or other advertisement so removed by the city may be recovered by the owner upon payment of $50.00 to the city within 14 days following removal of such sign. After the expiration of 14 days following impoundment of such sign, the city may dispose of such sign, and shall have no further obligation to the owner thereof. 
(Code 1968, § 3-2; Ord. No. 1998-7, § 2, 4-7-1998) 
Secs. 6-3-6-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DISTRIBUTION OF HANDBILLS, CIRCULARS, ETC. 

Sec. 6-23. - Restricted. 
    The practice of throwing, casting, scattering and depositing handbills, dodgers, circulars, booklets, posters, printed matter, advertising literature, advertising samples and devices, upon public and private property within the city without a written permit therefor from the city clerk is hereby declared to be a misdemeanor and constitutes a public nuisance. 
(Code 1968, § 3-12) 
Sec. 6-24. - Voluntary acceptance required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, cast, distribute, scatter, deposit or place upon any public or private place within the city, any handbill, dodger, circular, paper, booklet, poster, advertising sample or device, except that the same may be personally delivered to those who are willing to accept the same. 
(Code 1968, § 3-13) 
Sec. 6-25. - On or in automobiles restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, deposit or place in or on any automobile, or other vehicle, in the city, without first having obtained the permission of the owner or person in charge thereof, any handbill, dodger, circular, newspaper, paper, booklet, poster, printed matter, advertising literature, sample or device. 
(Code 1968, § 3-14) 
Sec. 6-26. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be jointly enforced by the city police department and the city planning and zoning department. 
(Code 1968, § 3-19; Ord. No. 1998-7, § 3, 4-7-1998) 
Sec. 6-27. - Penalties for violations. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $500.00. 
(Code 1968, § 3-20; Ord. No. 1998-7, § 3, 4-7-1998) 
Chapter 10 - AIRPORTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Aviation, MCA 1972, § 61-1-1 et seq. 

Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Aeronautics means transportation by aircraft; the operation, construction, repair, or maintenance of aircraft, aircraft power plants and accessories; the design, establishment, construction, extension, operation, improvement, repair, or maintenance of airports or other navigation facilities; and air instruction. 
    Air navigation means the operation or navigation of aircraft in the air space over the city, the airport, or any land acquired by the city in whatever manner as a takeoff or landing place for aircraft. 
    Aircraft means any contrivance used or designed for navigation of or flight in the air. 
    Airport means any area of land or water within the city which is established and designed for the landing and takeoff of aircraft, whether or not facilities are provided for shelter, servicing, or repair of aircraft, or for receiving or discharging passenger or cargo, and all appurtenant areas used or suitable for airport buildings or other airport facilities, and all appurtenant rights-of-way. 
    Civil aircraft means any aircraft other than a public aircraft. 
    Commission means the Mississippi Aeronautics Commission. 
    Director means the state director of aeronautics. 
    Navigable air space means air space above the minimum altitude of flight prescribed by the laws of the United States. 
    Operation of aircraft or operate aircraft means the use of aircraft for the purpose of air navigation, and includes the navigation or piloting of aircraft. Any person who causes or authorizes the operation of aircraft, whether with or without the right of legal control (in the capacity of owner, lessee, or otherwise) of the aircraft, shall be deemed to be engaged in the operation of aircraft within the meaning of the applicable provisions of this Code, state law and city ordinances, rules and regulations. 
    Public aircraft means an aircraft exclusively in the service of any government or any political subdivision thereof, including the government of any state, territory, or possession of the United States, or the District of Columbia, but not including any government-owned aircraft engaged in carrying persons or property for commercial purposes. 
(Code 1968, § 4-1) 
Sec. 10-2. - Cooperation with federal and state governments. 
    The mayor and board of aldermen are hereby authorized to cooperate with the governments of the United States and the state, and any agency or department thereof, in the acquisition, construction, enlargement, improvement, maintenance and operation of airports and other air navigation facilities in the city situated within or beyond the city limits, and to comply with the provisions of the laws of the United States and of the state and any regulations made thereunder for the expenditure of federal and state monies upon such airports and other navigation facilities. 
(Code 1968, § 4-2) 
Sec. 10-3. - Federal, state and other donations. 
    The mayor and board of aldermen are hereby authorized to accept, receive, and receipt for federal, state and other monies, either public or private, for and in behalf of the city for the acquisition, construction, improvement, maintenance, and operation of airports and other navigation facilities upon such terms and conditions as are or may be described by the laws of the United States and of the state and any rules or regulations made thereunder. 
(Code 1968, § 4-3) 
Sec. 10-4. - Qualification of pilots. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the city or at the airport, to navigate or attempt to navigate any aircraft carrying a passenger, who is not then the holder of an appropriate effective certificate, permit or license issued by that branch of the United States Government charged with the issuance thereof under the laws of the United States, authorizing said person to carry passengers in aircraft for hire or reward. 
(Code 1968, § 4-4) 
Sec. 10-5. - Possession, display of certificate. 
    The pilot's certificate, permit or license shall be kept in the personal possession of the person to whom issued when he is navigating or attempting to navigate aircraft within the city or at the airport, and must be presented for inspection upon the demand of any paying passenger, or any peace officer, or any official, manager or employee in charge of any airport operated by, or under the city jurisdiction. 
(Code 1968, § 4-5) 
Sec. 10-6. - Compliance with regulations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to navigate or attempt to navigate any aircraft within the city, or at the airport who does not comply with the rules, regulations, franchises and directives designated, promulgated and initiated by the state aeronautics commission, insofar as those permits, rules, regulations, franchises and directives do not conflict with the laws, rules, regulations, franchises and directives of any federal agency authorized and preempting such jurisdiction. 
(Code 1968, § 4-6) 
Sec. 10-7. - Unlawful to operate aircraft unless the same is licensed and inspected. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to navigate, attempt to navigate, or cause to attempt or navigate any aircraft within the city, or at the airport, unless the owner or operator thereof has complied with all of the rules and regulations pertaining to the licensing and inspecting of such aircraft by such branch of the United States and the state governments as may be charged with the responsibility therefor under any existing or hereafter enacted law. 
(Code 1968, § 4-7) 
Sec. 10-8. - Reckless operation of aircraft. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an aircraft in the air, on the ground, or on water, in or over the city or at the airport, while under the influence of intoxicating liquor, narcotics, or other habit-forming drugs; or in a careless or reckless manner so as to endanger the life or property of another; or in pursuit, chase, hunt, or effort to kill any wild game or waterfowl from aircraft. In any proceeding charging careless or reckless operation of aircraft in violation of this section, the court in determining whether the operation was careless or reckless shall consider the standards for safe operation of aircraft prescribed by federal and state laws and regulations governing aeronautics. 
(Code 1968, § 4-8) 
Sec. 10-9. - Cooperation with other officials in administration of chapter. 
(a)  The mayor and board of aldermen are authorized to confer with, or appoint representatives to confer with or to hold joint hearings with any agency of the United States and of the state in connection with any matter arriving under this chapter, or relating to the sound development of aeronautics. 
(b)  The mayor and board of aldermen are authorized to confer with, or appoint representatives to avail themselves of the cooperation, services, records and facilities of the agencies of the United States and of the state as fully as may be practicable in the administration and enforcement of this chapter; and said governing body, or its appointed representatives shall furnish to the agencies of the United States and of the state their cooperation, services, records, and facilities, insofar as may be practicable. 
(Code 1968, § 4-9) 
Sec. 10-10. - Report of accidents. 
    The mayor and board of aldermen, or their appointed representatives, shall report to the appropriate agencies of the United States and of the state all accidents in aeronautics within the jurisdiction of said governing body, and shall insofar as is practicable preserve, protect, and prevent the removal of the component parts of any aircraft involved in an accident to be investigated by the appropriate federal and state agencies. 
(Code 1968, § 4-10) 
Chapter 14 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Local Option Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, MCA 1972, § 67-1-1 et seq.; local option regulations concerning alcoholic beverages, Code Miss R. 48 080 001 (Regulation 16). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Intoxication. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to be or to become drunk in any public place in the city in the presence of two or more persons. Any person found guilty of violating this section shall be fined in any amount not exceeding $100.00. 
(Code 1968, § 5-1; Ord. No. 2007-10, § 1(5.1), 7-3-2007) 
State Law reference- Public drunkenness prohibited, MCA 1972, § 97-29-47. 
Sec. 14-2. - Persons who may not be sold to and persons who may not purchase. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any persons to sell, furnish, dispose of, give or cause to be sold, furnished, disposed of, or given, any alcoholic beverage to any person under the age of 21 years. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or furnish any alcoholic beverage to any person who is known to be insane or mentally defective, or to any person who is visibly intoxicated, or to any person who is known to habitually drink alcoholic beverages to excess, or to any person who is known to be an habitual user of narcotics or other habit-forming drugs. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 21 years to purchase, receive, or have in his possession in any public place, any alcoholic beverages. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 21 years to knowingly make a false statement to the effect that he is 21 years old or older to any person engaged in the sale of alcoholic beverages for the purpose of obtaining the same. 
(Code 1968, § 5-2; Ord. No. 1981-21, § 1, 9-1-1981)
