    Automotive vehicles or trailers of any kind or type without current license plates shall not be parked or stored on any residentially zoned property other than in completely enclosed buildings. Violations of this section shall be punished in accordance with chapter 1, General Provisions, section 1-8, General Penalties, Continuing Violation; Abatement of Nuisances, Continuing Violations. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § III.7, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 87-48. - Parking in the front yard. 
(a)  No person shall park a vehicle or trailer within the front yard as defined in section 117-195 of the land development code of any residentially zoned property or within a single-family subdivision except on a hard surface designed for parking. Further, off-street parking in the C-E, R-E, R-A, R-1A, R-B and R-C districts and any single-family subdivision shall not exceed a coverage of 40 percent of the area located within the required front yard area of any lot used for single-family, two-unit or zero lot line residential dwellings. 
    This section does not intend to create practical difficulties on affected properties. Where there are unusual circumstances peculiar to the site and where a literal application of specific provisions of this article would result in practical difficulties to the owner, a property owner may petition the mayor and board of aldermen for relief from specific provisions of this section. The petition requesting relief from the requirements of this section shall include a description of the property, the exact nature of the proposed relief, and the grounds upon which it is requested. Relief may be granted by the mayor and board of aldermen if the petitioner demonstrates that the granting of such relief will not adversely affect the surrounding properties nor otherwise be detrimental to the public welfare. The petition shall be filed with the city clerk for the city. 
(b)  Special events. Parking of vehicles shall be permitted in the front yard of any residentially zoned parcel or any parcel within a single-family subdivision for special events. Except for home football game weekends and Double Decker weekend, parking in the front yard shall be allowed for special events after a permit has been issued by the city clerk. Permit fees shall be $25.00 each and no more than two permits shall be issued per parcel in a calendar year. Special event parking for home football games and Double Decker weekend shall be limited in duration from 12:00 noon Friday to 12:00 noon Sunday. All other special event parking for which a permit is required shall be limited to 12 hours in duration. In no instance shall vehicles parked in the front yard for special events impeded public safety. 
(c)  Violations of this section shall be punished in accordance with chapter 1, General Provisions, section 1-8, General Penalties, Continuing Violation; Abatement of Nuisances, Continuing Violations. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § III.8, 5-5-2015) 
Secs. 87-49-87-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - LIVABILITY 

Sec. 87-61. - Number of unrelated occupants in single-family areas. 
    Homes in certain zoning districts of the City of Oxford are designated for occupancy by a single-family. However, this section does not preclude enforcement of any occupancy regulations in zoning districts other than those listed in subsection (2) below. 
(1)  Definitions. 
a.  For purposes of this section, the definition of a "family" is the same as the definition of that term contained in the City of Oxford Land Development Code (see section 117.66), that is, one or more persons who are related by blood, adoption, marriage, or foster care living together and occupying a single housekeeping unit with single culinary facilities, or a group of not more than three persons living together by joint agreement and occupying a single housekeeping unit with single culinary facilities on a nonprofit, cost sharing basis. Any household employees residing on the premises shall not be considered as a separate family for purposes of this definition. 
b.  The terms "occupancy" or "occupy" shall mean the use of a dwelling unit or portion thereof for living, sleeping, and cooking or eating purposes. 
c.  To the extent necessary, this section adopts all definitions set forth in the City of Oxford Land Development Code. 
(2)  Limited number of unrelated individuals. All dwelling units located in (A) Agricultural District, (C-E) Country Estate District, (R-E) Residential Estate District, (R-A) Single-Family Residential District, (R-1A) Single-Family Residential District, and areas of planned unit developments (PUDs) developed as single-family residential subdivisions shall be restricted to occupancy by a family as defined, in subsection (a) above. No person who is not part of such a family may occupy any such dwelling unit. 
(3)  Violation; prima facie proof of occupancy. Prima facie proof of occupancy of a dwelling unit by more than three unrelated persons is established in any prosecution for violation of this section if it is shown that the same four or more vehicles with registration to persons having different surnames or addresses were parked overnight at the dwelling unit a majority of nights in any 14-day period. This establishment of a prima facie level of proof in this subsection does not preclude a showing of "occupancy" of a dwelling unit by a person in any other manner. 
(4)  Violation by owner, occupant or lessee. It shall also be a violation of this section for any owner, occupant, or lessee of any dwelling unit described in subsection (b) above to permit or fail to prohibit the occupancy of such dwelling unit by more than three unrelated persons. 
(5)  Enforcement. The City of Oxford's Code Enforcement Officer shall enforce this section as follows: 
a.  When a complaint is received by the building official, the code enforcement officer shall initiate an investigation to determine if a violation may exist. This investigation shall be completed within 90 days of the complaint. 
b.  If the code enforcement officer determines there are more than three unrelated people residing in any dwelling unit described in subsection (2) above, the code enforcement officer shall contact all identifiable property owners and occupants by certified mail and request voluntary compliance. 
c.  If compliance is not achieved in a reasonable amount of time, the code enforcement officer shall again contact all identifiable property owners and occupants by certified mail and inform all such parties that they have 30 days from the date of the certified letter to comply with the restrictions or municipal court citations may be issued. 
d.  No municipal court citation shall be issued unless and until the procedures described above have been followed. 
(6)  Penalties. For each violation of this section, each owner, occupant, or lessee of a single-family dwelling shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $300.00 for each violation. Each day during which any violation of this section shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § IV.1, 5-5-2015) 
Sec. 87-62. - Number of unrelated occupants in residential areas other than single-family. 
    To help preserve neighborhood livability and quality and to insure adequate public services, infrastructure and parking; the occupancy of detached single-family dwelling units in residential areas other than those zoned single-family shall be as follows: 
(1)  When all occupants of a detached single-family dwelling unit within an RB zoning district are not related to each other by blood, adoption, marriage, or foster care, the number of occupants in a unit shall not exceed four such occupants. 
(2)  When all occupants of a detached single-family dwelling unit within an RC zoning district are not related to each other by blood, adoption, marriage, or foster care, the number of occupants in a unit shall not exceed five such occupants. 
(3)  The terms "occupancy" or "occupy" shall mean the use of a dwelling unit or portion thereof for living, sleeping, and cooking or eating purposes. 
(4)  To the extent necessary, this section adopts all definitions set forth in the City of Oxford Land Development Code. 
(5)  Violation; prima facie proof of occupancy. Prima facie proof of occupancy of a dwelling unit by more than three unrelated persons is established in any prosecution for violation of this section if it is shown that the same four or more vehicles with registration to persons having different surnames or addresses were parked overnight at the dwelling unit a majority of nights in any 14-day period. This establishment of a prima facie level of proof in this subsection does not preclude a showing of "occupancy" of a dwelling unit by a person in any other manner. 
(6)  Violation by owner, occupant or lessee. It shall also be a violation of this section for any owner, occupant, or lessee of any dwelling unit described in subsection (2) above to permit or fail to prohibit the occupancy of such dwelling unit by more than three unrelated persons. 
(7)  Enforcement. The City of Oxford's Code Enforcement Officer shall enforce this section as follows: 
a.  When a complaint is received by the building official, the code enforcement officer shall initiate an investigation to determine if a violation may exist. This investigation shall be completed within 90 days of the complaint. 
b.  If the code enforcement officer determines there are more than three unrelated people residing in any dwelling unit described in subsection (2) above, the code enforcement officer shall contact all identifiable property owners and occupants by certified mail and request voluntary compliance. 
c.  If compliance is not achieved in a reasonable amount of time, the code enforcement officer shall again contact all identifiable property owners and occupants by certified mail and inform all such parties that they have 30 days from the date of the certified letter to comply with the restrictions or municipal court citations may be issued. 
d.  No municipal court citation shall be issued unless and until the procedures described above have been followed. 
(8)  Penalties. For each violation of this section, each owner, occupant, or lessee of a single-family dwelling shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $300.00 for each violation. Each day during which any violation of this section shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § IV.2, 5-5-2015) 
Chapter 90 - PUBLIC AMUSEMENTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of municipality to regulate circuses, carnivals and fairs, etc., MCA 1972, § 21-19-33. 

Sec. 90-1. - Hours of operation of poolroom, billiard hall, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a poolroom or billiard hall after 12:00 midnight and before sunrise of the next day. It shall further be unlawful for any person to play any such game of pool or billiards or similar such game, in any poolroom, billiard hall or other place of amusement during such hours. 
(Code 1968, § 23-1; Ord. of 6-6-1966, § 1; Ord. No. 1973-24, § 1, 11-6-1973) 
State Law reference- Certain minors prohibited from entering poolrooms or billiard halls, MCA 1972, § 97-5-11; drinking, betting prohibited in poolrooms, billiard halls, MCA 1972, § 27-17-65. 
Sec. 90-2. - Skating rinks; location restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a skating rink within the city at any place or any lot within 200 feet of an occupied dwelling house, hotel or boardinghouse, in connection with which skating rink there is used any drum, band or other music. 
(Code 1968, § 23-2) 
State Law reference- Local privilege tax on skating rinks, MCA 1972, § 27-17-351. 
Sec. 90-3. - Hours of operation of bowling alley, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a bowling alley or other place of amusement after 2:00 a.m. and before sunrise of the next day. It shall further be unlawful for any person to play any such game in such places of amusement during such hours. 
(Code 1968, § 23-3; Ord. No. 1973-25, § 1, 11-6-1973) 
Sec. 90-4. - Poolroom or billiard hall; certain minors prohibited. 
(a)  No owner or manager of any poolroom or billiard hall, and no agent or employer of any such owner or manager shall permit any person under the age of 15 years, unless such person under the age of 15 years is accompanied by a responsible adult, to enter and remain in any poolroom or billiard hall. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, a poolroom or billiard hall shall not be deemed to include a place of amusement, either for profit or otherwise, wherein the operation of pool and billiard tables is not the main attraction held out to the public, or the primary amusement engaged in by the participants and wherein less than 15 percent of the gross revenue derived directly from the operation of such amusement or recreation center within the same room or immediately connecting and adjacent room shall be derived or indirectly from the operation of such pool or billiard tables and further, all nonprofit corporations, associations and organizations, and educational religious institutions, shall not be considered as operating poolrooms or billiard halls for the purpose of this section. 
(Code 1968, § 23-4; Ord. No. 1987-10, § 1, 11-3-1987) 
Chapter 94 - SOLID WASTE 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 94-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Ashes shall include the waste products of coal and other fuel used for heating and cooking from all public and private establishments and from all residences. 
    Garbage shall include all putrescible wastes, except sewage and body wastes, including vegetable and animal offal and carcasses of dead animals, but excluding recognized industrial byproducts, and shall include all refuse or accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable matter, liquid or otherwise, that attends the preparation, use, cooking, consumption, merchandising or storing of meat, fish, fowl, fruits or vegetables. 
    Health officer as used herein means the zoning administrator, or any duly authorized designee. 
    Refuse shall include garbage, rubbish, ashes and other putrescible and nonputrescible wastes except sewage, from all public and private establishments and residences. 
    Trash shall include all nonputrescible waste except ashes, from all public and private establishments and from all residences. 
(Code 1968, § 12-1; Ord. No. 1986-9, § 1, 7-1-1986) 
Sec. 94-2. - City dump, designation. 
    The mayor and board of aldermen shall, by appropriate resolution, designate from time to time property owned and used by the city as a city dump, and the use thereof shall be subject to the rules and regulations promulgated for such use by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(Code 1968, § 12-2) 
Sec. 94-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-20, § I.3, adopted May 5, 2015, repealed § 94-3, which pertained to littering prohibited-generally and derived from the Code of 1968, § 12-3 and Ord. No. 2008-5, adopted May 20, 2008. 
Sec. 94-4. - Same-Duty of business owners, occupants. 
(a)  Generally. The owner or occupant of any store or other place of business situated within the city shall exercise reasonable diligence at all times to keep his premises clean of wastepaper, wrapping paper, paper napkins, cartons, package containers, and other used or waste materials thrown or left on said premises by its customers, and to take reasonable measures to prevent same drifting or blowing to adjoining premises. 
(b)  Receptacles. Receptacles of sufficient size and number shall be placed on the premises accessible to the customers of such business where the above referred to articles of waste may be disposed of. 
(c)  Signs. Each and every business establishment shall place upon its premises in a conspicuous place or places in close proximity to the receptacle or receptacles above referred to, a sign or signs which shall, in essence, convey to its customers a request that they use such receptacles for the disposal of waste material. 
(Code 1968, § 12-4) 
Sec. 94-5. - Same-Duty of customer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any customer going upon the premises of another to in any manner dispose of wastepaper, wrapping paper, paper napkins, cartons, package containers, and other used or waste materials except in receptacles provided for such purposes. 
(Code 1968, § 12-5) 
Sec. 94-6. - Offensive accumulations prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make, use, or permit in any dwelling house, shop, store, factory, outhouse, cellar, yard, lot or any other place within the city, a noisome or offensive liquid, or substance of any character whatever, prejudicial to the health, or so offensive to the sight or smell as to be a nuisance to the neighborhood or liable to become so. 
(Code 1968, § 12-6) 
Secs. 94-7-94-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MANDATORY FLOW OF MUNICIPAL SOLID WASTE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- The Three Rivers Solid Waste Management Authority, operator of a regional solid waste landfill in Pontotoc County, adopted a mandatory flow resolution on Sept. 19, 2006, concerning municipal solid waste within the boundaries of the authority. The provisions within this article were adopted by the City of Oxford as required by state law. 

Sec. 94-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Industrial solid waste means solid waste generated by manufacturing or industrial processes that is not a hazardous waste regulated under Subtitle C of RCRA. Such waste may include, but is not limited to, waste resulting from the following manufacturing processes means electric power generation; fertilizer/agricultural chemicals; food and related products/by-products; inorganic chemicals; iron and steel manufacturing; leather and leather products; nonferrous metals manufacturing/foundries; organic chemicals; plastics and resins manufacturing; pulp and paper industry; rubber and miscellaneous plastic products; stone, glass, clay, and concrete products; textile manufacturing; transportation equipment; and water treatment. This term does not include mining waste or oil and gas waste. 
    Municipal solid waste means any nonhazardous solid waste resulting from the operation of residential, commercial, governmental, industrial or institutional establishments except oil field exploration and production waste, sewage sludge, rubbish which is disposed of in a Class I Rubbish Site or a Class IT Rubbish site and recycled material. 
    Municipal solid waste management facility means any land, building, plant, system, motor vehicles, equipment or other property, whether real, personal or mixed, or any combination of either thereof, used or useful or capable of future use in the collection, storage, treatment, utilization recycling, processing, transporting or disposal of municipal solid waste, including transfer stations, incinerators, sanitary landfill facilities or other facilities necessary or desirable. 
    Solid waste means any garbage, or refuse, sludge from a wastewater treatment plant, water supply treatment plant, or air pollution control facility and other discarded material, including solid, liquid, semi-solid, or contained gaseous material resulting from industrial, commercial, mining, and agricultural operations, and from community activities, but does not include solid or dissolved materials in domestic sewage, or solid or dissolved materials in irrigation return flows or industrial discharges that are point sources subject to permit under 33 USC 1342, or source, special nuclear, or by-product material as defined by the Atomic Energy Act of 1954, as amended (68 Stat. 923). 
(Ord. No. 2006-22, § 2, 10-17-2006) 
Sec. 94-32. - Transportation of municipal solid waste. 
    All municipal solid waste generated with the geographic boundaries of the city that is placed in the waste stream for disposal within the State of Mississippi shall be transported to, stored and managed at the Three Rivers Solid Waste Management Authority Landfill in Pontotoc County, Mississippi or at a transfer station owned by the Three Rivers Solid Waste Management Authority or its members. 
(Ord. No. 2006-22, § 3, 10-17-2006) 
Sec. 94-33. - Requirements for exemption from article. 
(a)  Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, this chapter shall not be applicable to any solid waste disposed of by a generator of industrial solid waste within the region which has provided for the collection, transportation and disposal of its solid wastes either directly or by contract for at least ten consecutive years or since the inception of the generator within the region if less than ten years immediately prior to enactment of this chapter at a single municipal solid waste management facility. 
(b)  A generator of industrial solid waste within the region which meets the criteria for this exemption shall seek a permit confirming this exemption from the authority pursuant to a procedure established by the authority. The permit for an exemption shall be valid for five years from the date of issuance and may be reissued for consecutive five year periods as long as the generator continues disposal in the same single municipal solid waste management facility. 
(c)  Any generator of industrial solid waste which locates within the region after the effective date from which this chapter is derived shall comply with the mandatory flow requirements set forth herein and shall not be entitled to this exemption. 
(Ord. No. 2006-22, § 4, 10-17-2006) 
Sec. 94-34. - Violation, penalty. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision of this article. Such violation shall be a misdemeanor and shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. For purpose of this Code, each day a violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2006-22, § 5, 9-19-2006) 
Secs. 94-35-94-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 

Sec. 94-51. - Authority of city. 
    The city may provide for the collection and disposal of garbage, refuse and trash, regulate the manner and times of such collection and disposal, establish the rates to be charged therefor, and otherwise make such rules and regulations pertaining to garbage, refuse and trash as may be desirable to assure the public health and welfare. 
(Code 1968, § 12-18) 
Sec. 94-52. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-20, § I.2, adopted May 5, 2015, repealed § 94-52, which pertained to containers and derived from the Code 1968, § 12-19; Ord. No. 1975-3, adopted March 4, 1975; Ord. No. 1983-11, adopted November 1, 1983; Ord. No. 2000-12, adopted June 20, 2000; Ord. No. 2003-19, adopted October 21, 2003 and Ord. No. 2005-7, adopted August 2, 2005. 
Sec. 94-53. - Accumulation prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant or lessee of any building, yard or lot of ground within the city to allow garbage, refuse or rubbish of any kind to accumulate or remain in such building, or upon such yard or lot, except where such garbage, trash or refuse is placed in a container. 
(Code 1968, § 12-20) 
Sec. 94-54. - Removal of garbage, etc., from food handling establishments. 
    All hotels, restaurants, public boardinghouses and other food handling establishments are required to remove all garbage, kitchen refuse and decaying matter incident to such business daily. 
(Code 1968, § 12-21) 
Sec. 94-55. - Collection service for certain materials not provided by the city. 
    Trash collection shall not be provided by the city for the following types of material which must be disposed of by and at the expense of the person responsible for its production: 
(1)  Materials used in the construction, repair, or demolition of the buildings or other structures, to include, but not be limited to, lumber, plaster, roofing, bricks, asphalt, concrete block or broken slabs, doors, windows, floor covering, or any other type of construction debris. 
(2)  Tree stumps weighting in excess of 50 pounds, provided, however, that no tree stumps resulting from commercial or contracted tree cutting, trimming, or clearing operations shall be collected by the city. 
(3)  Tree trunks or limbs in excess of four feet in length, and six inches in diameter, provided, however, that no tree trunks or limbs resulting from commercial or contracted tree cutting, trimming, or clearing operations shall be collected by the city. 
(Code 1968, § 12-22; Ord. No. 1985-10, § 1, 9-17-1985) 
Sec. 94-56. - Cover required for vehicles hauling garbage, etc. 
    All vehicles used in hauling garbage, trash or refuse of any kind whatsoever on any street or highway within the city shall have beds of tight construction to prevent the contents from falling or shifting onto the street, highway or ground, and shall at all times, except when loading or unloading, be covered with a canvas cover or some comparable cover. 
(Code 1968, § 12-23) 
Sec. 94-57. - Placing garbage, etc., on property of another prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dump or place or cause to be dumped or placed any garbage, refuse or trash of any kind whatsoever upon any public or private property of another located within the city without prior consent of the owner thereof. 
(Code 1968, § 12-24)

Any entity that contracts with a commercial hauler shall provide the City of Oxford with sufficient proof of such contract no later than five business days prior to the effective date of the contract. --- (2) --- 
Note- The business shall use assigned dumpster or bag garbage and place it in a container. 

Sec. 94-59. - Authority of city-Terms and conditions. 
(a)  As authorized by chapter 17 of the MCA of 1972, as amended, (Solid Wastes Disposal Law of 1974) the city has entered into a Solid Waste Disposal Service Agreement with the Three Rivers Solid Waste Management Authority (the Authority). Accordingly, disposal of all residential, commercial, industrial or governmental solid waste which is required or permitted by the Mississippi Department of Environmental Quality (DEQ) to be disposed of in a lawfully permitted landfill, shall be disposed of in accordance with all rules, regulations or policies of the authority and all rules, regulations or policies of the DEQ. All fees or other charges for disposal of such solid waste shall be as established by the authority. 
(b)  The city may own and operate a rubbish disposal site at a location or locations determined by the city. Such rubbish disposal site may be used by any person, business, corporation, or other entity situated within the county. Use of such facility by persons, businesses, corporations, or other entities situated outside the county shall be allowed only after approval by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(c)  The following regulations shall apply to the operation of the city rubbish disposal site: 
(1)  The site shall be open between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. Monday through Friday and from 7:00 a.m. to 11:30 a.m. on Saturday. The rubbish site shall be closed on Sunday and all legal holidays observed by the city. 
(2)  All persons or entities authorized to utilize the rubbish site shall do so only at specific locations designated by city sanitation department personnel. 
(3)  No person shall dispose or attempt to dispose any material into the rubbish site which is prohibited by the DEQ or any other authority having jurisdiction over the rubbish disposal site. The city sanitation department is hereby authorized to promulgate regulations and rules which further prohibit, restrict or regulate the disposal of material into the rubbish disposal site. 
(d)  The city may establish, in cooperation with the Three Rivers Solid Waste Management Authority, or upon its own motion, facilities for the collection and recycling of used tires, used appliances, scrap metal or other recyclable material. 
(Code 1968, § 12-27; Ord. No. 1988-12, § 1, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 1990-7, § 1, 6-19-1990; Ord. No. 1991-16, § 1, 7-16-1991; Ord. No. 1992-1, § 1, 1-7-1992; Ord. No. 1993-10, § 3, 10-19-1993; Ord. No. 1998-6, § 1, 4-7-1998) 
Sec. 94-60. - Same-Fees established. 
(a)  The following fees shall be charged by the city for the use of the rubbish disposal site: 
(1)  City residents who dispose of rubbish from their residence ..... No charge 
(2)  Commercial, industrial, governmental or other entities located within the city or the county, per ton ..... $26.00 
(3)  County residents who dispose of rubbish from their residence, per ton ..... $26.00 
(4)  Other commercial, industrial, governmental, individual, or other entities located outside the county...Fees shall be as determined by mayor and board of aldermen. 
(5)  Minimum charge ..... $5.00 
(6)  Disposal of used tires with rims removed: 
Four wheeler, boat trailer tires, etc., each ..... $0.50 
Automobile and light truck tires, each ..... $1.00 
Large truck tires, each ..... $5.00 
Tractor, heavy equipment tires, each ..... $10.00 
(7)  Disposal of used appliances, scrap metal means...There shall be no charge for disposal of used appliances. The hauler of such materials shall unload such in a location as directed by city personnel and shall place all appliances containing Freon separate from other materials 
(b)  The total charge to each customer shall be as determined by the net weight of each load on the basis of scale weight. In the event the scales become inoperable, the charge shall be on the basis of $6.00 per cubic yard as measured by city sanitation department personnel. 
(c)  Payment for use of the rubbish disposal site shall be by cash or check at the time of disposal, provided however, that upon request and approval by the city, monthly statements may be sent to governmental, commercial, industrial, or other entities. Charges to residents of the county residing outside the city, who dispose of rubbish from their own residence, may at the option of the board of supervisors of the county, be paid for by the county. 
(d)  Any person, business, industry, agency or other entity who shall deposit unacceptable rubbish into the site shall be required to immediately remove such unacceptable rubbish from the site and shall be responsible for the cost of removal, transportation or proper disposal of such rubbish or any corrective action, remediation or penalty resulting therefrom. The city reserves the right to refuse to accept, in its entirety, any load containing unacceptable rubbish or other material. 
(Code 1968, § 12-28; Ord. No. 1988-12, § 2, 9-6-1988; Ord. No. 1990-7, § 2, 6-19-1990; Ord. No. 1990-14, § 1, 8-10-1990; Ord. No. 1991-15, § 1, 7-16-1991; Ord. No. 1992-1, § 2, 1-7-1992; Ord. No. 1993-10, § 4, 10-19-1993; Ord. No. 1994-17, § 1, 11-1-1994; Ord. No. 1998-6, § 1, 4-7-1998; Ord. No. 2016-3, 1-5-2016) 
Sec. 94-61. - Dumpsters or compactors. 
(a)  The mayor and board of aldermen may authorize the solid waste superintendent to designate areas in which all businesses must utilize dumpsters or garbage compactors provided by the city in a central location within the city. 
(b)  In the downtown business district, all businesses must deposit their garbage, refuse, or trash inside the designated dumpster or compactor. It shall be unlawful for any business to place, deposit, or abandon any garbage, refuse, cans, bottles, trash, or any form of litter anywhere outside of any dumpster or compactor, on or near any street, sidewalk, curb, or right-of-way. This includes garbage, refuse or trash that is bagged and/or contained in garbage cans or curbside bins. It shall also be unlawful for any business to deposit any garbage, refuse, or trash within any enclosure surrounding their designated dumpster or compactor. 
(c)  Any violation of this section shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 90 days, and the cost of prosecution, or by both such fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the municipal judge. Each day any violation of this section shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2011-1, § I, 1-4-2011) 
Chapter 98 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS, ROADS AND BRIDGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of governing authority to regulate streets, MCA 1972, §§ 21-19-1, 21-19-31, use of streets for utilities' purposes, MCA 1972, §§ 21-27-3, 21-27-5, 21-27-7; power to exercise full jurisdiction over streets, MCA 1972, § 21-37-3; power to construct and maintain sidewalks, MCA 1972, § 21-37-5; closing streets, MCA 1972, § 21-37-7; power to provide street lighting, MCA 1972, § 21-37-11. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 98-1. - Spitting on streets, sidewalks, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to spit on the streets or sidewalks or on any steps, floors, or walls of any public building, church, theater, depot, store, office or shop frequented by the public or within the enclosure of any taxicab, carriage or vehicle of like kind used as a common carrier for the accommodation of the public. 
(Code 1968, § 25-1) 
Sec. 98-2. - Sidewalks and gutters to be kept clear. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to keep the sidewalks and gutters in front of one's place of business clear and free from all trash, dirt, slush or slops, and any or all obstructions whatsoever. 
(Code 1968, § 25-2) 
Sec. 98-3. - Tacks, nails, not to be thrown in streets, sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or cause to be thrown onto any of the streets or sidewalks or onto the public square of the city any tacks, nails or other sharp materials, objects and instruments which would hurt or injure the feet of any pedestrian or animal or injure the tires of any bicycle, motorcycle, automobile or other vehicle. 
(Code 1968, § 25-3; Ord. of 5-5-1964, § 2) 
Sec. 98-4. - Paving, barricades not to be torn down or subgrade driven over. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to destroy, remove or take down any barricades erected to protect the pavements or repairs to the pavements of this city, or drive over pavements, concrete foundations or subgrade that has not been opened to the public use by the city engineer. 
(Code 1968, § 25-4) 
Sec. 98-5. - Property owners to remove dead trees. 
    Property owners who have trees with dead limbs overhanging the sidewalk shall remove the limbs or trees after having received three days' notice from the chief of police so to do. 
(Code 1968, § 25-5) 
Sec. 98-6. - Obstruction of streets, sidewalks-Generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct in any way, any street, alley or sidewalk in the city. However; when in the public interest and after consultation with the appropriate city departments, the mayor may temporarily detour traffic on a public street for a period not to exceed six hours. 
(Code 1968, § 25-6; Ord. No. 2012-16, § 1, 12-4-2012) 
Sec. 98-7. - Same-Declared nuisance. 
    All obstructions in and to any of the streets, alleys or sidewalks in the city are hereby declared nuisances and, excepting fences and buildings which obstruct or encroach on any street, alley or sidewalk, the same shall be removed upon an order so to do by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(Code 1968, § 25-7) 
Sec. 98-8. - Same-Building or fence. 
(a)  When any building or fence shall obstruct or encroach on any street, alley or sidewalk, the same shall be removed or caused to be removed by the city after ten days' written notice shall have been given to the owner of any such obstructing fence, or after 60 days' notice to the owner of any such obstructing building. 
(b)  The cost of removal of any obstructing or encroaching building, fence or other thing, shall be charged to the party who placed the obstruction in or on the sidewalk, street or alley, or to the owner of any such fence or building, and such cost shall be recovered by the city by suit against such party if necessary. In addition thereto, such party shall be subject to the penalties prescribed in section 1-8 for the violation of this section. 
(Code 1968, § 25-8) 
Sec. 98-9. - Street numbering. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of each and every owner or occupant of each and every dwelling or building within the corporate limits to have the same numbered in accordance with the official numbering system prescribed by the city. 
(b)  Each dwelling or building shall have its street address prominently displayed upon the premises. Said address shall be clearly visible from the nearest street or other public way providing access to such dwelling or building. Numbers shall be placed upon the front of such dwelling or building facing the nearest street or other public way, or may be placed on mailboxes or other devices placed in the front yard. 
(c)  Numbers for multiple occupancies (duplexes, apartment buildings, office buildings, shopping center, etc.) shall be displayed upon, or in close proximity to, the primary entrance to such occupancies, irrespective that the number may also be displayed upon a mailbox or other device. 
(Code 1968, § 25-9; Ord. No. 1998-17, § 1, 8-18-1998) 
Sec. 98-10. - Rain, wastewater not to drain into streets, sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any gutters, water pipes, or other means of conveying water from the roofs, floors, tanks in or of buildings, sheds or the like to permit or allow the water conveyed thereby to be emptied onto any sidewalk or paved street in the city. 
(Code 1968, § 25-10) 
Sec. 98-11. - Discharging filthy liquids into streets, drains. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge from his house, factory, lot, premises, or from any other place, by use of a pipe, tiling, bucket, vessel, or in any other way into any street, avenue, alley, gutter, ditch, or drain anywhere in the city, any household or kitchen slop or slop water, and soapsuds or dyestuff, or any kind of liquid manures, or other filthy liquids whether from closet, privy, or elsewhere, or any substances noisome or offensive to the sight or smell of persons residing, or passing near the place of such discharge, or to use any street, avenue, sidewalk, alley, gutter, or ditch as a drainage to carry off the same. 
(Code 1968, § 25-11) 
Sec. 98-12. - Vending machines, displays on sidewalks prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, establish or maintain any vending machine, display of merchandise, stand or other obstruction or any advertisement on any public sidewalk in the city. 
(Code 1968, § 25-12; Ord. of 5-5-1964, § 2) 
Sec. 98-13. - Driveway culverts, pipes, and drains. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install, place or otherwise construct any type of driveway culvert, pipe, drain, or drainage structure upon any street or road right-of-way within the city without first obtaining approval from the city engineer. Such culvert, pipe or drain to be installed shall be the size and type of material as specified by the city engineer. Any person who fails to obtain approval prior to installation of such culvert, pipe, drain or other drainage structure, shall, upon notice from the city engineer, immediately remove such culvert, pipe, drain or other drainage structure at their expense. 
(Code 1968, § 25-13; Ord. No. 1995-10, § 1, 7-18-1995) 
Sec. 98-14. - Use of street right-of-way. 
    Any person proposing to use any municipally owned street right-of-way within the city for any private purpose other than installation of a driveway or driveway culvert as specified in section 98-13, or related to trees as specified in sections 98-132 through 98-143, shall first obtain approval from the city director of public works. In the event approval is obtained from the city director of public works, the applicant shall sign a release and waiver of liability regarding such private facility or improvement. Such private facility or improvement shall include, but not be limited to, installation of underground sprinkler systems, retaining walls, fences, lighting systems, etc.; provided, however, that no street right-of-way shall be used for parking or storage of vehicles or equipment; display of merchandise; or erection of any sign. Erection of buildings, balconies, supported canopies, stairways and the like may be permitted upon review and approval by the mayor and board of aldermen. The city, in granting approval to use the right-of-way for any private purpose, does not in any way assume maintenance or upkeep of the facility or improvement, nor will the city be held responsible for any damage which may be inadvertently done to such improvement regardless of the source or cause of such damage. The city may, at any time, direct that such facility or improvement be removed from the right-of-way at the expense of the owner, except in instances whereby a permanent easement has been granted by the mayor and board of aldermen. Any damage to city facilities (including, but not limited to, damages to sidewalks, streets, curb, underground utilities and storm drains) shall be repaired by the owner and approved by the city director of public works before any private facilities or improvement is occupied. 
(Code 1968, § 25-14; Ord. No. 1997-4, § 1, 4-15-1997; Ord. No. 2001-11, § 1, 9-18-2001) 
Sec. 98-15. - Use of public parking spaces and blocking of city streets during construction projects. 
(a)  During on-going construction projects, individuals and businesses involved in the construction project frequently make use of public parking areas for storage and/or temporary placement of equipment, machinery, materials, dumpsters, and other private property. Anyone so using public parking areas for 30 minutes or more per day shall be assessed a fee of $10.00 per day for each space, or any portion thereof, so used. This fee shall accrue for each day, or any portion thereof in excess of 30 minutes, Monday through Saturday, that the public parking area is so used. Should other public areas adjacent to public parking be so used, then the city may, at its sole discretion, assess a fee on that use of up to $10.00 per day for each additional 200 square feet of public property being used. 
(b)  Any time that a street is blocked, or substantially blocked, for a period of four or more hours in any 24 hour period, the person blocking the street shall be assessed a fee of $100.00 for that day. This fee shall accrue for each day, Sunday through Saturday, that the street is so blocked for four or more hours. Should there be any doubt as to whether a street has been substantially blocked, the director of public works for the city shall make the necessary determination. The person blocking or substantially blocking the street shall be responsible for insuring the safe flow of traffic in the area and for any expenses related to directing or re-routing traffic. Should the city police department or the director of public works determine that conditions in the area warrant that the city provide personnel or equipment to direct or re-route traffic, the person blocking or substantially blocking the street shall reimburse the city for the costs of such personnel or equipment. 
(c)  Any individual or business who intends to make such use of a public parking area or who intends to block or substantially block a city street shall estimate the total amount of fees due under this chapter and pay those fees prior to using public parking areas or blocking a city street. Should the actual use or blockage exceed the estimated fees, then the city may collect the difference. In the alternative, should any individual or business make such use of public parking areas or block city streets without first paying the estimated fees described herein, fees may be assessed by any city official visiting the building site and a 20 percent penalty shall be added. However, any individual or business that pays, in good faith, an estimated amount for fees prior to using public parking areas or blocking a street shall not be assessed a penalty. 
(d)  The fees described herein must be satisfied and evidence of payment provided before a certificate of zoning compliance will be issued for the building. 
(e)  Should the city determine that, in any particular location or at any particular time, such use of public parking areas or such blocking of a city street will either impose a danger or cause unreasonable inconvenience to the city, its citizens, or their property, the city reserves the right to limit the scope of use of public parking areas or limit the extent to which a city street may be blocked or refuse permission to use public parking areas or to block a city street. 
(f)  By accepting the fee described herein, the city in no way agrees to accept responsibility for any private property placed in a public parking area or on a city street, nor does the city grant any right to continuing use or future use of the public parking area or city street. 
(g)  The city may, at any time, direct that any private property, debris, or other material be immediately removed from public parking areas or city streets at the owner's expense. 
(h)  To insure the health, safety, and welfare of the driving and pedestrian public, for all building projects within the City of Oxford, the public works director or his or her written designee in consultation with the chief of police or his or her written designee, are authorized to enact a traffic control plan which shall address and regulate the flow of vehicular and pedestrian traffic to and from a building site, the timing and method of loading and unloading vehicles at the building site, and any other issue(s) which the public works director and chief of police (or their designees) determine are pertinent to the efficient, safe, and orderly flow of traffic in and around the building site. 
(i)  This section in no way limits or abrogates any other section governing the use of public parking areas or of city streets. 
(Code 1968, § 25-14.1; Ord. No. 2002-14, 12-17-2002; Ord. No. 2014-23, 6-3-2014) 
Sec. 98-16. - Fees for recordation. 
    In any instance whereby an easement or other legal document is determined to be necessary or appropriate in granting permission to use the street right-of-way, the applicant shall pay to the city the actual cost of recording such document in the chancery clerk's office. 
(Code 1968, § 25-15; Ord. No. 1997-4, § 1, 4-15-1997) 
Sec. 98-17. - Penalties for violations. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $1,000.00, and/or sentenced up to six months in jail, or both. 
(Code 1968, § 25-15.1; Ord. No. 1998-17, § 2(25-15-A), 8-18-1998) 
Secs. 98-18-98-38. - Reserved.
