ARTICLE III. - PATHWAY COMMISSION 

Sec. 98-64. - Pathway-Commission established. 
(a)  There is hereby established a pathways commission consisting of seven members appointed by the mayor and approved by the board of aldermen. One member shall be a designated representative of the city park commission and one member shall be a designated representative police department. Members of the commission shall serve three year staggered terms. Members shall serve without compensation; however, the city, if prior approval has been obtained by the mayor and board of aldermen, may pay certain expenses incurred by the commission. Members may reside in the city or the county. The commission may receive and communicate with the county board of supervisors as it wishes. 
(b)  Members of the commission may select their own officers, which may include a chairman, vice-chairman and secretary. Meetings of the commission shall be held as determined by the commission, but at least quarterly and shall be open to the public. A majority of the members present shall constitute a quorum. Records of attendance and all matters before the commission shall be maintained, and a designated city staff person shall serve the commission in a secretarial and/or liaison capacity. 
(c)  The commission shall be responsible for updating and maintaining the Oxford's 2003 Comprehensive Bicycle and Pedestrian Plan. The city's bicycle and pedestrian plan provides a framework for the development of safe and convenient bicycle and pedestrian access to all areas of the city, university, and areas of interest outside of the city limits. 
(d)  The city's pedestrian plan shall be presented annually to the mayor and board of aldermen at a regularly scheduled meeting in June. 
(e)  The commission, when requested by the mayor and board of aldermen, shall consider, investigate, make findings, report and recommend upon any matter within the scope of its jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 2007-9, § 1(I), 6-19-2007) 
Sec. 98-65. - Same-Engineering. 
    The pathways commission shall recommend, through grants or donations or within established or otherwise reasonable budgetary guidelines, to the public works department, the city's park commission, and the mayor and board of aldermen, general or specific areas of the city where improvements or new construction that enhance pedestrian and bicycle access may be made and develop strategies in association with the public works department, the planning office, and the city's park commission to enhance and increase the city's pedestrian and bicycle resources. 
(Ord. No. 2007-9, § 1(II), 6-19-2007) 
Sec. 98-66. - Same-Education. 
    Develop programs with the city school district (including safe routes to schools), and the city police department and other community organizations to educate children and adults about safe pedestrian and bicycle habits, and motorists about their responsibilities for pedestrian and cyclist safety. 
(Ord. No. 2007-9, § 1(III), 6-19-2007) 
Sec. 98-67. - Same-Encouragement. 
    The pathways commission shall promote bicycling and walking for health, fitness, transportation, and recreation through events, programs and other activities which benefit residents, businesses and visitors of all ages and abilities. These activities will be coordinated with local bike clubs, schools, health organizations and other partners. 
(Ord. No. 2007-9, § 1(IV), 6-19-2007) 
Sec. 98-68. - Same-Enforcement. 
    The city will provide balanced enforcement of the state and city vehicle and traffic laws for motorists, pedestrians and bicyclists. This will include enforcement of pedestrian rights-of-way in crosswalks, bicyclists riding with traffic and all modes sharing the road safely. 
(Ord. No. 2007-9, § 1(V), 6-19-2007) 
Sec. 98-69. - Same-Evaluation. 
    The pathways commission shall provide an annual assessment to the board of aldermen through the collection of data on the number of foot and bike trips on the city's streets and pathways and through the collection of public comments concerning the perceived safety and usability city streets, sidewalks and pathways by pedestrians and bicyclists of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2007-9, § 1(VI), 6-19-2007) 
Secs. 98-70-98-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EROSION CONTROL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-26, § I, adopted July 1, 2014, amended article IV in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former article IV, §§ 98-90-98-97, pertained to similar material, and derived from the Code of 1968, §§ 25-23-25-30; Ord. No. 2005-4, adopted May 3, 2005; Ord. No. 2007-6, adopted March 6, 2007 and Ord. No. 2007-11, adopted July 3, 2007. 

Sec. 98-90. - Title. 
    This article shall be known as the erosion and sediment control ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2014-26, § I, 7-1-2014) 
Sec. 98-91. - Jurisdiction. 
    The regulations set forth in this article shall apply to all property within the permitting jurisdiction. This article shall be a minimum standard. 
(Ord. No. 2014-26, § I, 7-1-2014) 
Sec. 98-92. - Purpose. 
    During the construction process, soil is most vulnerable to erosion by wind and water. Eroded soil endangers water resources by reducing water quality and causing the siltation of aquatic habitat for fish and other desirable species. Eroded soil also necessitates repair of sewers and ditches, dredging of watercourses, and causes air quality impacts when sediment particles become entrapped in the atmosphere. In addition, clearing and grading during construction causes the loss of native vegetation. Vegetation holds the soil in place, holds and filters stormwater, provides habitat for terrestrial and aquatic life, and provides a healthy living environment for Oxford citizens. 
    As a result, the purpose of this local regulation is to safeguard persons, protect property, prevent damage to the environment and promote the public welfare by guiding and regulating the design, construction, use, and maintenance of land disturbances in the City of Oxford. 
(Ord. No. 2014-26, § I, 7-1-2014) 
Sec. 98-93. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Best management practice (BMP) means an action which landowners, developers, and/or contractors can take to reduce the impact of human activity on the natural environment. BMPs to control pollutant discharges from land disturbance can be divided into two main categories: structural and nonstructural measures to minimize quantity and maximize quality of stormwater runoff from a construction site. BMPs can include sediment and erosion control measures, good housekeeping measures, and stormwater measures. Erosion and sediment controls can each be further described as permanent controls and/or temporary controls. BMPs shall meet or exceed recognized effective industry standards as outlined in the Field Manual (see Field Manual). 
    BMP minimum requirements means those basic and standard practices, devices and/or policies as set forth and approved by the city enforcement officers, to serve as a minimal (but not inclusive) level of protection on all sites requiring a land disturbance permit, including single-family residential. 
    Buffer means land that serves as a protective barrier. A buffer may include undisturbed vegetation and/or re-establishment of vegetation. 
    City official means the designated city official. 
    Construction sign means the signage to be included on each site requiring a land disturbance permit. Signage shall include at a minimum "Construction Site - No Trespassing", the contractor's name, 24-hour emergency contact number for the contractor, the name of the QCP, and a 24-hour emergency contact number for the QCP. Signage shall be visible from the street, public right-of-way, or proposed public right-of-way. Signage shall not be larger than three square feet and shall be considered a temporary sign in accordance with the City of Oxford's Land Development Code. 
    Control measures means those best management practice devices as specified on the stormwater pollution prevention plan (aka SWPPP plan), as well as those specified in the Field Manual. Control measures may include, but are not limited to, hay bales, silt fences, earthen berms, retaining walls, temporary or permanent ditch checks, check dams, riprap dams, stormwater retention devices or sediment traps, and any measure certified by an Mississippi Professional Engineer or QCP. 
    Critical areas means environmentally and ecologically sensitive areas to include but not limited to high risk areas for erosion and/or those within 100 feet of floodways, floodplains, wetlands, water courses and gullies, whether applicable to a single-family dwelling or otherwise. 
    Drainage way means any channel that conveys surface runoff through the site, whether intermittent or permanent. 
    Entity means any property owner, lessee, contractor, utility company, person, firm, corporation, or any legal entity, and their employees and agents. The term "entity" shall include all entities with authority or control over the property in issue. 
    Erosion control means measures that prevent erosion (process by which the land surface is worn away). 
    Field Manual means the most current issue of "Field Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control on Construction Sites in Mississippi" - Second Edition (2005) from the Mississippi Department of Environmental Quality and provides guidance for the prevention or minimization of problems related to erosion, sedimentation and stormwater management on construction sites and erodible urban areas. The Field Manual provides a basis for developing sound plans and implementing appropriate measures (BMPs). 
    Grading means altering the shape of ground surfaces to a predetermined condition; this includes, but is not limited to stripping, cutting, filling, stockpiling and shaping or any combination thereof, and shall include the land in its cut or filled condition. 
    Land disturbance for purposes of this article, means any grading, filling, draining, excavating, ditching or other earthmoving operation which could result in damage to adjacent lands, public or private, from erosion thereto or siltation thereof shall be deemed land-disturbance activity. The cutting of trees (i.e. silviculture) that does not create or aggravate erosion shall not be deemed land-disturbance. 
    Land disturbance permit means a permit issued by the City of Oxford for the construction or alteration of ground. 
    Municipal property means property owned by the city including, but not limited to, city streets, rights-of-way, and storm drainage systems. 
    Perimeter control means a barrier that prevents sediment from leaving a site either by filtering sediment-laden runoff or diverting it to a sediment trap or basin. 
    Phasing means land disturbance of a parcel of land in distinct phases, with the stabilization of each phase before the clearing of the next. 
    Pollutant includes, but is not limited, to dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, chemical wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discarded equipment, rock, sand, silt, sediment and industrial, municipal and agricultural waste discharged into water. 
    Property means private or municipal property. 
    QCP means "qualified credentialed professional" include a registered engineer, landscape architect or land surveyor, a professional geologist, a registered forester, a registered environmental manager as determined by the National Registry of Environmental Professionals (NREP),a certified professional soil scientist (CPSSc) as determined by American Registry of Certified Professionals in Agronomy, Crops, and Soils (ARCPACS), successful completion and certification of a construction stormwater management course offered by Mississippi Department of Transportation (MDOT), and other department accepted professional designations, certifications, and/or accredited university programs that can document requirements regarding proven training, relevant experience, and continuing education, that enable recognized individuals to prepare CBMPPs, to make sound professional judgments regarding Mississippi National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) rules, the requirements of this chapter, planning, design, implementation, maintenance, and inspection of construction sites, receiving waters, BMPs, remediation/cleanup of accumulated offsite pollutants from the regulated site, and reclamation or effective stormwater quality remediation of construction associated land disturbances, that meet or exceed recognized technical standards and guidelines, effective industry standard practices, and the requirements of this chapter. The QCP shall be in good standing with the authority granting the registration or designation. 
    Sediment means topsoil, dirt, mud, sand, gravel, silt, debris or any other material. 
    Sediment control means measures that prevent and/or minimize eroded sediments from leaving the site. 
    Silviculture means the care and cultivation of trees; forestry. 
    Stabilization means practices that prevent exposed soils from eroding. 
    Start of construction means beginning with the first land disturbance activity associated with a development, including installation of BMPs, and followed by land preparation such as clearing, excavation, grading, and filling. 
    Stormwater pollution prevention plan (SWPPP) means the SWPPP addresses all pollutants and their sources, including sources of sediment associated with construction, construction site erosion, and all other activities associated with construction activity. Prevention of pollutants in stormwater, to the maximum extent practicable, is controlled through the implementation of best management practices (BMPs). This plan identifies site specific measures and sequencing to be used for the control of erosion and sediment on a development site before, during and after construction. 
    Watercourse means gullies, rivers, streams, intermittent streams, ditches, brooks, channels, lakes ponds, manmade ponds, estuarine waters, swamps, bogs, vernal pools, and all other bodies of water, natural or artificial, intermittent or permanent, public or private which have defined banks of water at least a portion of each year. 
    Waterway means a channel that directs surface runoff to a watercourse, or to the public storm drain. 
    Wetland means areas and waters that are inundated or saturated by surface water or ground water at a frequency and duration sufficient to support, and under normal circumstances do support, a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated conditions. Wetlands generally include, but are not limited to, lands and water meeting this definition and otherwise often referred to as swamps, marshes, bogs, wetland meadows, ephemeral and tributary streams, grady ponds, vernal pools, banks, reservoirs, ponds, lakes and lands under water bodies. The primary ecological parameters for identifying wetlands include hydric soils, hydrophytic vegetation, and hydrologic conditions reflecting temporary or permanent inundation or saturation. 
(Ord. No. 2014-26, § I, 7-1-2014; Ord. No. 2017-8, § I, 8-15-2017) 
Sec. 98-94. - Permits. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall engage in any land disturbance activity within the city permitting jurisdiction until the landowner has obtained a land disturbance permit therefore from the city. No land disturbance permit will be issued for any property on which indebtedness to the city exists due to the city's removal of sediment in accordance with section 98-100(d). Once permit is received, permittee should immediately install those control measures (BMPs) specified on the site storm water pollution prevention plan, if any, the city BMP minimum requirements, and the construction sign. 
    If ownership of property is transferred, new owners are responsible for maintaining or updating requirements of the erosion and sediment control ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2014-26, § I, 7-1-2014; Ord. No. 2017-8, § II, 8-15-2017) 
Sec. 98-95. - Stormwater pollution prevention plan (SWPPP) 
(a)  Applicable for all developments requiring site plan approval including, multifamily, subdivisions, commercial and industrial construction, and single-family residences over one acre, and/or those in critical areas. 
(b)  The stormwater pollution prevention plan shall be prepared by a certified erosion and sediment control specialist, such as a qualified credentialed professional (QCP), a certified professional of erosion and sediment control (CPESC) and/or a professional engineer. 
(c)  The plan shall at a minimum include the following: 
(1)  The name of the project; 
(2)  Intended use of the property; 
(3)  Map identifying topography, natural features such as watercourses, waterways, and wetlands, buffers, and proposed construction areas. 
(4)  The building site with corresponding dimensions scaled at no more than one inch equals 100 feet; 
(5)  The name, address and telephone number of the owner or lessee of the property; 
(6)  Construction phasing details describing the intended sequences of construction activities, including clearing and grubbing, excavation and grading, utility and infrastructure installation, final grading and landscaping, and any other activity at the site that results in soil disturbance. Sequencing shall identify the estimated duration of exposure of cleared areas. 
(7)  The specific erosion control plans proposed, as specified herein below; 
a.  The name, address and telephone number of the entity performing such work; 
b.  Total area to be cleared, graded, excavated or filled; 
c.  General description of work to be performed. 
d.  Erosion and sediment controls used throughout all phases of construction and details of permanent stabilization methods to be used at completion. 
e.  Provisions for maintenance of erosion and sediment controls. 
f.  Contact information for person responsible for inspecting the site each week and following rain events. 
(d)  Submittal, review, and approval procedures. 
(1)  The stormwater pollution prevention plan shall be submitted in conjunction with the land disturbance permit application. 
(2)  For sites requiring a stormwater permit from the state department of environmental quality (MDEQ), a copy of such approved permit shall also be submitted as part of the application for the permit. Any work to be performed within any 100-year floodplain area shall also be identified on maps or plats showing the existing elevations of the property, the 100-year floodplain and floodway areas, and the location and elevation of proposed fill material. No permit shall be required prior to beginning work in an emergency situation to repair or restore utility service. An application shall be made for a permit for all emergency cuts, digging, or excavations within 48 hours after the cuts, digging, or excavations have been made. However, a prospective applicant shall give verbal notice immediately to the building official or his or her designee upon determination that "emergency" work or construction is needed. 
(3)  Review of each stormwater pollution prevention plan shall be within 30 days of submittal to determine the plan's conformance with these provisions. 
(4)  The city shall: 
a.  Review the plan with reasonable, justifiable conditions to accomplish objectives and ensure that the plan meets or exceeds the provisions of the city BMP minimum requirements and the Field Manual. 
b.  City may elect to require a third party review for sites in or near critical areas. 
(e)  Modifications to the plan. 
(1)  Major modifications to the stormwater pollution prevention plan, such as the redesign of BMPs or removal of BMPs, shall be submitted to the city building department and shall be processed and approved, or disapproved, in the same manner as the original plan. 
(2)  Minor modifications to the stormwater pollution prevention plan, such as the use of additional temporary BMPS, may be addressed on site as needed to ensure compliance with the provisions. 
(3)  If a BMP failure occurs, as deemed by the city inspector, the city may require that the stormwater pollution prevention plan be modified and resubmitted. 
(f)  All sites, including single-family residential, shall comply with the city BMP minimum requirements specifications, as well as the stormwater pollution prevention plan (if any). 
(Ord. No. 2014-26, § I, 7-1-2014) 
Sec. 98-96. - Design requirement. 
    Erosion control practices, sediment control practices, and waterway crossings shall meet the design criteria set forth in the most recent version of the Field Manual and shall be adequate to prevent transportation of sediment from the site to the satisfaction of the city. 
(1)  Clearing and grading. 
a.  Clearing and grading of natural resources, such as wetlands, waterways, and watercourses, shall not be permitted, except when in compliance with all other chapters of this Code and any and all federal, state and local regulations. 
b.  Clearing techniques that retain natural vegetation and natural drainage patterns are strongly encouraged. 
c.  A buffer area within the front, side, and rear setbacks is required The buffer area can either be the existing vegetation that is left undisturbed or re-establishment by planting new vegetation if clearing or grubbing is required within setbacks. If setbacks are not required, perimeter control measures are expected to act as buffer. 
d.  Multi-stage phasing may be required on sites, with the size of each phase to be established by the QCP and approved by the city. The stormwater pollution prevention plan should clearly delineate each phase of clearing and the estimated duration of exposed soils. 
e.  Clearing, except as is necessary to install BMPs, shall not begin until the city's BMP minimum requirements are met 
f.  Cut and fill slopes shall be no greater than 3:1, except as approved by the city. 
g.  Developers requesting city sewer and/or water services must obtain site plan approval prior to clearing regardless of property location. If clearing occurs outside permitting district prior to obtaining site plan approval, then connection to city utilities shall be denied for up to 18 months from date of request for services unless necessary remedies are approved by planning director and city engineer. The delay will not apply to single-family residential construction that is less than one acre. 
(2)  Erosion control. 
a.  Stabilization requirements. Any area of land from which the natural vegetative cover has been either partially or wholly cleared or removed by development activities shall be revegetated within 21 days from the substantial completion of such clearing and grading. The following criteria shall apply to revegetation efforts: Reseeding must be done with an annual or perennial cover crop accompanied by placement of a mulch material or its equivalent of sufficient coverage to control erosion until such time as the cover crop is established over 90 percent of the seeded area. 
b.  Areas in the setbacks must be stabilized within 21 days of being disturbed. 
c.  If vegetative erosion control methods, such as seeding, have not germinated to a coverage of at least 90 percent within 21 days, the city may require that the site be reseeded, sodded, or stabilized with alternative cover. 
d.  Replanting with native woody and herbaceous vegetation must be accompanied by placement of mulch material or its equivalent of sufficient coverage to control erosion until the plantings are established and are capable of controlling erosion. Revegetation sites must exhibit a survival rate of at least 75 percent of the cover crop throughout the year immediately following the revegetation. Revegetation must be repeated in successive years until the minimum 75 percent survival rate for one year is achieved. 
e.  On steep slopes or in drainage ways, special techniques that meet or exceed design criteria outlined in the Field Manual shall be used to ensure stabilization. 
f.  Soil stockpiles must be stabilized at the end of each work week or if a rain event is predicted. 
g.  Techniques, as referenced the Field Manual shall be employed to prevent the blowing of dust or sediment from the site onto adjacent properties. The use of chemical agents in or near critical areas is discouraged. 
h.  Right-of-way disturbances shall be stabilized with sod or a combination of sod and seed/mulch. Seed and mulch alone shall not be acceptable. 
i.  Techniques shall be employed to divert upland runoff past or around disturbed slopes. 
(3)  Sediment controls. 
a.  Sediment controls shall be provided in the form of perimeter controls, such as silt fences, sediment basins and/or sediment traps. 
b.  Where possible, sediment basins shall be designed in a manner that allows adaptation to provide long term stormwater management. 
c.  Adjacent properties shall be protected. 
(4)  Waterways and watercourses. 
a.  When a watercourse must be crossed regularly during construction, a temporary stream crossing shall be provided. When applicable, approval must be obtained from the United States Army Corps of Engineers, state and federal agencies, and the city. 
b.  When in-channel work is conducted, the channel shall be stabilized after the work is completed. 
c.  Any construction of a crossing of a waterway or watercourse in a floodway must be engineered with a no-rise certificate and shall have minimal temporary or permanent disturbance of the floodways bottom condition. 
d.  All on-site stormwater conveyance channels shall be designed according to the criteria outlined in the Field Manual. 
e.  Outlets of all pipes and paved channels shall have adequate stabilization to prevent erosion. Riprap may be required for stabilization if vegetative measures prove to be ineffective at controlling erosion in waterways or watercourses. 
(5)  Construction site access. 
a.  A stabilized construction access (construction entrance) shall be required on all development and construction sites, including single-family residence, in order to ensure sediment is not tracked on to public streets from the construction site. Stone pads shall be a course aggregate meeting the requirements for MDOT's Size I aggregate, be six inches thick and shall be placed a minimum width equal to existing drive (if existing) or 30 feet. The length of stone pad will be sufficient to prevent sedimentation from entering public streets from the construction site. 
b.  Sediment accumulation and tracking on public rights-of-way, such as streets, alleys, storm drains or sanitary sewers, ditches and sidewalks, is not allowed and shall be removed daily. 
(6)  Completion of construction activities. All open channels and ditches shall be permanently vegetated upon final building inspection. Seed and mulch shall not be accepted. If sod is used on slopes, corners will need to be pinned per the Field Manual. 
a.  Common areas, such as detention basins, shall be permanently stabilized upon final inspection. Seed and mulch shall not be accepted. 
b.  Prior to final inspection, all construction waste and debris, silt fences, hay bales, inlet protection, and other BMPs shall be removed, except those required for the next phase of construction, or those deemed necessary for continued stabilization by the building official. 
c.  The responsible party shall submit a letter to building official requesting termination of land disturbance permit upon completion of all construction activities and stabilization of property. 
(Ord. No. 2014-26, § I, 7-1-2014) 
Sec. 98-97. - Inspections. 
(a)  The QCP shall make weekly and rain event inspections of all control measures throughout the construction process to ensure the overall effectiveness of the storm water pollution prevention plan. 
(b)  City officials may also conduct erosion and sediment control inspections of the construction activity and shall determine compliance or noncompliance with the provisions of this article. City erosion and sediment control inspections in no way supersede or replace any state or federal inspection requirements. Building inspections may be refused or rescheduled if a site is found to be noncompliant. 
(c)  If erosion and sediment control inspections reveal deficiencies or failures of erosion control measures, the owner or their representative will be responsible for notifying the city and immediately begin correcting deficiencies in order to bring site into compliance. 
(Ord. No. 2014-26, § I, 7-1-2014; Ord. No. 2017-8, § III, 8-15-2017) 
Sec. 98-98. - Violations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to violate any provision(s) of this article. 
(b)  The city may issue violations for the following reasons: 
(1)  Violations of the terms of the permit. 
(2)  Site development which may adversely affect the health, welfare, or safety of persons residing or working in the neighborhood. 
(3)  Site development that is detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to property or improvements in the neighborhood. 
(4)  Violations which are detrimental to the environment, including sensitive habitats and aquatic resources. 
(5)  Any offsite sedimentation, including that which may occur inside inlets, storm drains, waterways or ditches, or on public or private property. 
(6)  Any water quality impact, as defined by state and/or federal agencies. 
(7)  Failure to notify the city engineer or his designated representative in code enforcement of deficiencies or failures of erosion control measures. 
(c)  Additionally, whenever the city determines that off-site sedimentation is occurring or has occurred as a result of a land disturbance activity, despite application and maintenance of protective practices, the person conducting the land disturbance activity or the person responsible for maintenance will be required to take additional protective action. Furthermore, if it is to be determined that sedimentation has occurred off site onto right-of-way, private property, waterways, manmade stormwater drainage systems, the sediment shall be removed in its entirety. 
    In stream and/or wetland sedimentation removal shall be determined by appropriate state and federal agencies. 
(Ord. No. 2014-26, § I, 7-1-2014; Ord. No. 2017-8, § IV, 8-15-2017) 
Sec. 98-99. - Enforcement and penalties for municipal and private properties. 
(a)  In the event any entity shall allow such sediment to be deposited upon adjacent or downstream property, such entity shall immediately remove such sediment from said property and report violation to the city engineer of his designated representative in code enforcement. Self-reported violations are considered violations. Failure to self-report along with any other violation of a provision of this ordinance will constitute separate violations. Enforcement and penalties will be imposed by the number of violations accrued. For example: Failure to self-report and failure to contain sediment within the limits of the site will be considered two independent violations. 
(b)  In addition to removing all sediment from adjacent properties the following stop work orders will be issued until the corresponding conditions are met: 
(1)  First violation. Stop work order issued to allow for the removal of sediment and installation of additional measures to prevent sedimentation from leaving the site in future rainfall events. 
(2)  Second violation. Stop work order issued for a minimum of one week to allow for removal of sediment and installation of additional measures to prevent sedimentation from leaving the site in future rainfall events, and inspection by QCP and city officials. 
(3)  Third violation. Stop work order issued and building permit revoked until board of alderman approve both removal of sedimentation and preventative efforts. The minimum period for revocation of the building permit and application of the stop work order shall be 30 days from the date the third stop work is issued to allow for removal of sediment, installation of additional measures to prevent sedimentation from leaving the site in future rainfall events, resubmission and approval of the storm water pollution prevention plan, and inspection by QCP and city officials. 
(c)  Any entity violating any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and fined not less than $500.00 nor more than $1,000.00 and/or six months in jail or both. Each 24-hour period after notice is given by the city official shall be considered a separate offense hereunder. Furthermore, an entity found guilty of such violation who failed to remove the sediment after notice is given, shall be required to pay to the city or private property owner restitution equaling the costs and expenses of removal. In calculating the costs and expenses incurred by the city, a reasonable rate shall be charged for use of all city equipment and employees, with such rate to be at least equal to the costs of contracting the removal of such sediment with a private entity. 
(d)  Should the city, or an agent thereof, undertake needed remedies due to contractor negligence, the city shall bill the permittee or responsible party for an amount based on actual costs of man hour labor and materials. This fee shall apply to, but not be limited to, city street, sidewalk, right-of-way and storm drain clean-up of sedimentation and/or other pollutants. The city may also withhold any forthcoming certificate of occupancies or final inspections that are relative to the clean-up charges, until the bill is paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 2014-26, § I, 7-1-2014; Ord. No. 2017-8, § V, 8-15-2017) 
Sec. 98-100. - Permit fees. 
    The permit fee for a land disturbance permit is as follows: 
Residential (one- and two-family) ..... $25.00 
Commercial and multifamily: (Three units or more), up to five acres ..... 250.00 
Plus, for each additional five-acre increment ..... 100.00 
(Ord. No. 2014-26, § I, 7-1-2014; Ord. No. 2016-18, 12-6-2016) 
Secs. 98-101-98-109. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-28, adopted July 1, 2014, amended article V in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former article V, §§ 98-110-98-113, pertained to similar material, and derived from the Code of 1968, §§ 25-38.11-25-38.14 and Ord. No. 2000-6, adopted March 7, 2000. 

Sec. 98-110. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to diminish threats to public health and safety caused by the runoff of excessive stormwater; reduce economic losses to individuals and the community at large; and protect, conserve and promote the orderly development of land and water resources. The provisions of this article further regulate, guide and control: 
(1)  The subdivision layout, redevelopment and improvement of lands located within the City of Oxford. 
(2)  The construction of buildings and drainage of the sites on which structures are located, including parking and other paved areas. 
(3)  The design, construction and maintenance of stormwater drainage facilities and systems. 
(4)  Any development located outside the city limits, but which seeks water and/or sewer service(s) to be provided by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2014-28, 7-1-2014) 
Sec. 98-111. - General criteria and standards. 
(a)  Applicability. This article shall be applicable within the City of Oxford's jurisdictional area and shall apply to any development which requires a site plan review according to section 212.02 of the land development code, any residential development where a development plan is required or any nonresidential development of three acres or more. This article shall also apply to any development having less than four acres and having 50% or greater impervious surface. 
(b)  Limitation on stormwater runoff. The drainage system will be designed so that, except in unusual circumstances, the rate of runoff of surface water from the site, in the condition in which it is proposed to be developed, will not exceed the rate of runoff from the site in its undeveloped or natural condition. 
    In addition to the requirement listed above, it shall be the responsibility of the developer and his Engineer to ensure that the run-off of the two-, ten, 25-, and 100-year storm events do not create a flooding problem within 500 feet of any run-off exit point from the property which did not pre-exist the development. The developer and his engineer shall also ensure that any pre-existing flooding problems are not worsened by the runoff leaving the site. 
(c)  Detention of excess stormwater runoff. The increased stormwater runoff resulting from the proposed development shall be detained by the provision of infiltration, vegetative, or structural means. Infiltration practices are those that facilitate the percolation of runoff through the soil to groundwater including infiltration basins/trenches, dry wells, and maintained porous pavement. Vegetative means are landscaping features that, with optimal design and good soil conditions, facilitate percolation of runoff. Examples include grassy swales, filter strips artificial wetlands and rain gardens. Structural means include retention or detention facilities designed to gather runoff in wet ponds, dry basins, or multi-chamber catch basins and slowly releasing it. 
(d)  Storage capacity. Retention or detention facilities shall be designed with sufficient capacity to accommodate all runoff caused by the development in excess of that runoff which would occur from the site if left in its natural, undeveloped condition. This storage shall be sufficient to store all excess rates of runoff for the two-, ten-, 25-, and 100-year storms of 24-hour duration. Storage shall also be sufficient to accommodate a storm with an intensity of three inches per hour with a one hour duration. 
    Peak flow (Q YEAR) . The peak flow shall be calculated for the two-, ten-, 25- and 100-year storms. The peak flows shall not be increased at any location for any storm, up to and including the 100 year storm (Q 100) . 
(e)  Discharge velocities. Post development discharge velocity from the drainage system shall not exceed theoretical pre-development velocity. Velocity dissipaters shall be required as described in the outlet control structure section of this article. 
(f)  Channel stability. The stormwater runoff from the proposed development shall not increase channel instability downstream. 
(g)  Retention/detention facilities in floodplains. If detention storage is provided within a floodplain of a major stream, no storage volume for the facility may be provided below the high water elevations established for that floodplain. 
(h)  Stormwater bypass. Drainage systems shall have adequate capacity to bypass, through the development, the natural flow from all upstream areas. 
(i)  Drainageway maintenance. It shall be unlawful to dump trash, debris, landscape waste and other deleterious materials in any and all drainageways in the city. 
(j)  Natural, undeveloped or existing condition. Reference to the natural, undeveloped or existing condition shall mean the condition of the site before any development occurred at any time. If the natural, existing condition cannot be documented through historical means, the pre-developed site will be evaluated using the slope currently present and with 50 percent of the site coverage designated as "wooded" and 50 percent of the site coverage designated as "grassed." The city engineer will provide the runoff curve numbers to be used for the natural, undeveloped or existing condition. 
(k)  Infiltration systems. Any design using infiltration structures should be designed to completely drain the water quality volume into the soil within 24 hours after the storm event and completely dewater between storms. 
    A scientifically credible field test method shall be used to measure the soil infiltration rate and the test results shall be included as part of the stormwater report. The minimum acceptable field measured soil infiltration rate is 0.3 inches per hour. Field measured soil infiltration rates should not exceed 5.0 inches per hour. 
(Ord. No. 2014-28, 7-1-2014) 
Sec. 98-112. - Improvement regulation. 
(a)  Required information. The following information and data prepared and certified by a registered professional engineer in the State of Mississippi, as indicated by signature and stamp, shall be furnished with the plans of each proposed residential, commercial and industrial development. 
(1)  Contour map . A topographic map with one-foot minimum interval contours, meeting National Map Accuracy Standards, of the land to be developed and such adjoining land whose topography may affect the layout or drainage of the property being developed. On such a map, the following shall be shown: 
a.  The banks and centerline of streams and channels; 
b.  The normal shoreline of lakes, ponds and retention/detention basins, and lines of inflow and outflow; 
c.  The locations, size and slope of stormwater conduits and drainage swales; 
d.  Storm, sanitary and combined sewers and outfalls of record; 
e.  Delineation of upstream and downstream drainage features and watersheds which might be affected by the development; 
f.  Base flood (100-year) elevation (BFE) and floodways for the property, established pursuant to Oxford's Flood Damage Prevention Ordinance; 
g.  Environmental features including the limits of wetlands areas and any designated natural areas. 
(2)  Drainage plan. A comprehensive drainage plan shall be designed to safely and completely handle the stormwater runoff and to detain increased stormwater runoff. This plan shall provide and be accompanied by a written report that includes maps and other descriptive material showing the following: 
a.  The extent and area of each watershed tributary to the drainage channels in the development; 
b.  The storm sewers and other storm drains to be built and the basis of their design to include but not limited to; the pipe diameter and linear footage used; the inlet location with surface and invert elevations; outfall or outlet location with surface and invert elevation; junction box location with dimensions, surface elevation, and entry and exit invert elevations; and any end treatments such as headwalls, end flares, rip-rap aprons, etc. 
c.  All receiving storm sewers, invert elevations, downstream slope, pipe size and material used; streams or channels, and its high water elevation and the functioning of the drains during high water conditions; 
d.  Existing streams and floodplains to be maintained and new channels to be constructed including their locations, cross-sections and profiles; 
e.  Proposed culverts and bridges to be built including their materials, elevations, waterway openings and basis of design; 
f.  Existing retention/detention facilities to be maintained, enlarged or altered and new facilities to be built including their design; 
g.  The estimated location and percentage of impervious surfaces existing and expected to be constructed when the development is completed; 
h.  The slope, type and size of all sewers, and other waterways; 
i.  Any proposed environmental enhancement or mitigation features; 
j.  Retention/detention basins to be built including a plot or tabulation of storage volumes with corresponding water surface elevations and of the basin outflow rates for those water surface elevations; 
k.  Retention/detention basins location and contours to be shown on grading plan; 
l.  Description of outlet control structure(s), function, and materials used; 
m.  Drawing details showing dimensions and materials of retention/detention outlet control structures; 
n.  For all retention/detention basins, design hydrographs of inflow and outflow for the two-, ten-, 25-, and 100-year peak flows from the site under natural and developed conditions; 
o.  Special consideration or instruction may be given regarding areas where the subject developer only owns a portion of the entire drainage basin or where the site is too small for reasonable design considerations. 
p.  The live detention storage to be provided shall be calculated on the basis on the two-, ten-, 25-, and 100-year frequency rainfall for a 24-hour duration as published by the U.S. Weather Bureau for this area and for a storm with an intensity of three inches per hour with a one-hour duration.; 
q.  Landscaping plan for retention/detention facility; 
r.  One or more typical cross-sections of all existing and proposed channels or other open drainage facilities, showing the elevation of the existing land and the proposed changes thereto, together with the high water elevations expected from stormwater runoffs under the controlled conditions called for by this article, and the relationship of structures, street and other utilities. 
(b)  Detention basins. Detention basins shall be constructed to temporarily detain the stormwater runoff in excess of the rate of runoff occurring on the site before development. A detention basin may be designed and constructed for permanent use as well. Both temporary and permanent detention basins will conform to the following standards: 
(1)  Storage volumes. The volume of storage provided in these basins, together with such storage as may be authorized in other detention facilities, shall be sufficient to control the excess rate of runoff from the two-, ten-, 25-, and 100-year storms for 24-hour duration and a storm with an intensity of three inches per hour with a one-hour duration. 
The volume of storage shall also be sufficient to control the excess rate of runoff from the Peak flow (Q YEAR) . 
(2)  Maximum depth. The maximum planned depth of stormwater stored shall not exceed five feet unless natural ground conditions lend themselves to greater depths. 
(3)  Approach slopes. The approach slopes of the basin shall conform as closely as possible to natural land contours. Regrading is allowable if necessary to keep the slopes under ten percent. Erosion control measures shall be provided as well as devices or measures to insure public safety. 
(4)  Dams and dikes. All detention dams or dikes shall be constructed as earth filled and non-overflow type dams with a minimum of one foot of freeboard on the structure for the 100-yr storm event. 
(5)  Outlet control structures. Outlet control structures shall be designed as simply as possible and shall operate automatically. They will be designed for multi-stage release to limit discharges into existing or planned downstream channels or conduits so as not to exceed predetermined safe capacities and not in excess of flows which would have occurred with the land in its natural, undeveloped condition for the two-, ten-, 25-, and 100-year storms. Velocity dissipation measures shall be employed to ensure that the discharge does not increase downstream erosion. A surface outlet control structure cannot discharge within 40 feet of an adjacent property line, unless approved by the city engineer. 
(6)  Spillway. Emergency overflow facilities shall be provided to pass the 500-year storm event unless positive measures are installed to control the inflow so as not to exceed the safe capacity of the basin. 
(7)  Appearance. Detention facilities shall where possible, use natural topography and natural vegetation. In lieu thereof, these facilities shall have planted trees and vegetation such as shrubs and permanent ground cover on their borders. 
A system will be designed and implemented to collect any trash that may have washed from the site and prevent it from entering the detention basin. This system will be designed so that it can be cleaned out on a regular basis. The system will also be designed so that the trash settles at the bottom of the collection area and does not prevent water from moving through the device and into the detention facility. 
(8)  Fencing. Detention structures shall be enclosed by a six-foot fence when required by the director of public works or his designated representative. 
(c)  Retention basins. Basins designed with permanent pools shall conform to the standards for detention basins as specified, unless modified or amended as follows: 
(1)  Minimum depths. The minimum normal depth of water before the introduction of excess stormwater shall be three feet. 
(2)  Facilities for emptying. For emergency purposes, cleaning or shoreline maintenance, facilities shall be provided or plans prepared for the use of auxiliary equipment to permit emptying and drainage. 
(3)  Pollution abatement. Aeration facilities may be required, dependent on the quality of the influent and detention time. 
(4)  Side slopes. The side slopes shall be of non-erosive material with a slope of 4:1 or flatter. The ledge shall be four to six feet wide, three feet below normal water depth and sloping gently toward the shore to prevent people or objects from sliding into deep water. There shall be a freeboard of 18 inches above the high water elevation on all retention basins. Alternate designs for side slopes may be considered under special circumstances where good engineering practice is demonstrated. 
(5)  Sediment storage. Adequate area for sediment storage shall be provided in all retention basins. 
(d)  Maintenance of facilities. All improvements, including landscaping, shall be maintained to perform as originally designed and constructed in perpetuity and cannot be developed for any other use which would limit or cause to limit the use of the improvements. The improvements shall be owned and/or maintained by the owner or property owner's association of the development and each property owner shall own a proportionate share of the improvements and shall bear his proportionate responsibility for the continued maintenance in accordance with the above. 
    Each property owner shall, within the contents of his deed, be liable for the combined maintenance of the improvements. A special note to this effect shall appear on any final plat of a subdivision or any plat of condominium and their declarations. 
    The property owner's association shall be formed by the developer in perpetuity for the maintenance of the improvements. Membership shall be mandatory by all property owners. Articles of agreement of the property owner's association must be approved by the board of aldermen of the City of Oxford before recording. 
    In subdivisions consisting of five single-family residential lots or fewer, the provision of a property owner's association may be waived, provided that other parts of this section have been met. 
    When problems arise due to inadequate maintenance, the public works director/city engineer or their designated representative of the City of Oxford may inspect the improvements and compel the correction of the problem by written notice. 
(e)  Inspection of facilities. All stormwater facilities are required to be inspected during and upon completion of construction by a licensed engineer. 
    The engineer responsible for the construction of the stormwater system shall inspect all drainage facilities while under construction. Upon completion of all site construction, the engineer responsible for the construction of the stormwater system shall submit a letter, bearing his signature and stamp, certifying that the facility was constructed and is operating according to the design plan submitted to the city. The city will, at the discretion of the building official and city engineer, reserve some form of service from the development until such certification letter is received, including but not limited to the final certificate of occupancy, water services, final acceptance of streets or utilities, or the final release of any bonds held. 
    The city engineer, or designated representative, may also inspect all drainage facilities any time after construction, in perpetuity, to ensure the long term function and maintenance of the approved design. When facilities are not constructed or maintained according to approved plans, the City of Oxford has the explicit authority to compel compliance and have any situations corrected which are not according to the approved plans. All drainage facilities located on private property shall be accessible at all times for inspection by the city engineer or other responsible public official. 
(f)  Regional detention. The requirements for on site retention/detention facilities may be waived by the City of Oxford if it is determined that a development project is too small, or if engineering, aesthetic or economic factors make a combined or regional facility more practical for construction by the city. In this case, the City of Oxford shall require a fee and/or dedication of land from the developer, which the City shall use to construct the regional facility. This fee and/or dedication of land shall be based on the proportionate share for the development in its completely developed state of the present costs of constructing the regional facility. 
(Ord. No. 2014-28, 7-1-2014) 
Sec. 98-113. - Miscellaneous. 
(a)  Penalties for violation. Any person found to be in violation of any of the terms and provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 or imprisoned for no more than 90 days or both such fined and imprisonment. A continuance of a violation without reasonable effort on the part of the defendant to correct it shall be and constitute a new and separate offense each day. 
(b)  Validity. If any term or provision of this article shall be held to be unconstitutional or otherwise unenforceable, the remainder thereof shall not be affected thereby and shall remain in full force and effect. 
(c)  Conflict. All ordinances heretofore adopted on the subject of the ordinance from which this article is derived which are in conflict herewith are hereby repealed and the application provisions of the ordinance are substituted in their place. 
(d)  Variances. The City of Oxford Board of Adjustments shall have the power to authorize variances from the provisions or requirements of this article as will not be contrary to the public interest. No variance from the strict application of any provision shall be granted unless it is found that: 
(1)  Special conditions and circumstances exist which are peculiar to the land, structure, or building involved and which are not applicable to other lands, structures, or buildings in the same district; 
(2)  Literal interpretation of the provisions of this article would deprive the owner of rights commonly enjoyed by other properties in the same district under the terms of this article; 
(3)  The special conditions and circumstances do not result from the actions of the applicant; 
(4)  Granting the variance requested will not confer on the applicant any special privilege that is denied by this article to other lands, structures, or buildings in the same district. 
(e)  Review of plan. Review of each stormwater plan shall be completed within 30 days of receipt by the public works department of a complete submittal. A complete submittal must meet the requirements of section 98-112(a)(2), drainage plan and shall include any construction grading plans required to determine the plan's conformance with the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2014-28, 7-1-2014) 
Sec. 98-114. - Repealing clause. 
    All ordinances, or resolutions of the mayor and board of aldermen of the City of Oxford that conflict with the provisions of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall be, and the same are hereby repealed, and rescinded, but only to the extent of such conflict. 
(Ord. No. 2014-28, 7-1-2014) 
Sec. 98-115. - Severability. 
    If any provision of article is determined by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid or otherwise unenforceable, such findings shall not effect the other provisions hereof, which shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 2014-28, 7-1-2014) 
Sec. 98-116. - Effective date. 
    This article shall become effective and be in force as provided by the law. 
(Ord. No. 2014-28, 7-1-2014) 
Secs. 98-117-98-131. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TREES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2008-5, § XI, adopted May 20, 2008, amended article VI in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former article VI, §§ 98-132-98-143, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Code 1968, §§ 25-39-25-50; and Ord. No. 1997-1, § 2, adopted Feb. 4, 1997. 

Sec. 98-132. - Title and objectives. 
(a)  This article shall be known as, and hereinafter referred to, as the city tree article. 
(b)  It is recognized that the preservation of trees enhances the natural scenic beauty, sustains the long term potential increase in property values which encourages quality development, aids in tempering the effect of extreme temperatures, helps to reduce air and noise pollution, furnishes habitat for wildlife and gives Oxford an identity and quality that enhances the environment for all residents and the business community and improves the attractiveness of the city to visitors. 
(c)  Based on the above stated reasons, the City of Oxford adopts this article for the preservation of the community's biological resources, including its trees. Furthermore, the city finds that: 
(1)  The policies of the city are to protect exisiting woodlands and their associated vegetation, protect important groves of trees, preserve riparian habitat, encourage the planting of native species, and avoid the cutting of mature trees. 
(2)  In order to implement these policies and to promote the public health, safety and welfare, it is necessary to adopt this article to protect existing trees and compensate the public when a protected tree is destroyed or removed in a manner that is not in compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(3)  The rights of individuals to maintain and develop their private property in a manner that is not contrary to the public health, safety and welfare shall be preserved. 
(Ord. No. 2008-5, § XI, 5-20-2008) 
Sec. 98-133. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases and words shall have meanings as herinafter defined: 
    City. The City of Oxford, Mississippi. 
    Code enforcement officer. The city code enforcement officer assigned to enforcement of the tree ordinance. 
    DBH (diameter breast height). The diameter of any tree measured four and one-half feet above ground line. 
    Department. Any of the several departmental divisions of the City of Oxford, Mississippi. 
    Dripline. A vertical line extending from the outermost edge of the tree canopy to the ground. 
    Historic tree. A tree of notable historic interest and value due to its association with the history of Oxford, Lafayette County or the University of Mississippi. 
    Person. Any individual, group, company, firm, corporation, partnership, association, society or any other combination of human beings, whether legal or natural, excluding any utility company or department of the city. 
    Specimen tree. A tree of extremely high value due to its species, size, age or other relevant criteria. 
    Superintendent. The city superintendent of building and grounds. 
    Tree. Any self-supporting, woody perennial plant, normally having one main trunk, of at least 15 feet at maturity. 
    Utility. Any public or private utility company owning and/or maintaining utility lines for the transmission of electricity, water, sewage, gas, telephone, television and the like. 
(Ord. No. 2008-5, § XI, 5-20-2008) 
Sec. 98-134. - Tree board established. 
(a)  There is herby created a tree board consisting of five members appointed by the mayor and board of aldermen. All members shall be residents of the City of Oxford. To the extent practicable, two members shall be professionals in related fields such as arborists, horticulturalists, foresters, landscape architects, or other persons knowledgeable in the area of urban forestry. The county agent and the county forester may serve as advisory, nonvoting members of the tree board. 
(b)  Members of the tree board shall serve a four-year term. Vacancies shall be filled by appointment for the remaining unexpired term. Members shall serve without compensation. Provided, however, that the mayor and board of aldermen may, if prior approval has been obtained, pay certain expenses incurred by the tree board. 
(c)  Members of the tree board may elect their own officers which may include a chairman, vice-chairman and secretary. Meetings of the tree board shall be held as determined by the tree board. A majority of the members present shall constitute a quorum. Records of attendance and all matters before the board shall be maintained. 
(d)  The tree board shall prepare a comprehensive tree plan for the care, preservation, planting and replanting of trees along municipal streets, parks or upon other municipal property. Such plan may also include the designation of an official city tree. The tree board may also prepare, as part of the comprehensive tree plan, an inventory of historic and specimen trees situated upon public or private property, as herinafter provided. The comprehensive tree plan shall be reviewed annually and updated as necessary. The comprehensive tree plan shall be presented annually to the mayor and board of aldermen at a regularly scheduled meeting in April. 
(e)  The tree board, when requested by the mayor and board of aldermen, shall consider, investigate, make findings, report and recommend upon any matter within the scope of its jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 2008-5, § XI, 5-20-2008) 
Sec. 98-135. - Administration and enforcement. 
(a)  As a matter of public policy, the city favors the preservation of large, mature trees. Large, mature trees are a vital component of the beauty, charm and character of the city. Mature trees also enhance the quality of life for all who live and work in the city. Once destroyed, a mature tree is virtually irreplaceable for the present generation of the citizens of the city. Therefore, to the extent possible, healthy, mature trees should be preserved. 
(b)  The city superintendent of buildings and grounds shall act in a nonvoting, advisory capacity to the tree board in all matters upon which said board has jurisdiction. The code enforcement officer, in consultation with the superintendent, shall have the authority to enforce and administer all rules, regulations or provisions contained herein. 
(c)  Decisions or determinations made by the code enforcement officer, in consultation with the superintendent, shall be presented to the tree board in a monthly report. The monthly report shall include all permits and other actions taken by the code enforcement officer and/or the superintendent relating to trees on municipal property, and shall include justification for the removal of any tree. Any person aggrieved by the decision of the code enforcement officer may appeal such decision to the mayor and board of aldermen who shall make a final determination of the matter. Appeals from the decision of the mayor and board of aldermen shall be as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2008-5, § XI, 5-20-2008) 
Sec. 98-136. - Trees on municipal property. 
    The city has exclusive jurisdiction over all trees existing or to be planted upon street right-of-ways, city parks or other municipal property. The city has authority to plant, prune, spray, treat, preserve tree situated upon municipal property in accordance with this article and to remove trees situated upon such property in accordance with section 98-137. The tree board is hereby delegated, in an advisory capacity, joint authority with the city over trees situated upon municipal property as expressed in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2008-5, § XI, 5-20-2008) 
Sec. 98-137. - Planting, pruning, treating, and excavating under trees on municipal property; protective fencing to be installed around municipal trees adjacent to construction sites. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, upon any municipal property, to prune, spray, treat, preserve or plant any tree, or excavate underneath the dripline of any tree without having obtained a tree permit from the code enforcement officer. For purposes of this section, the dripline shall be defined as follows: 
For a tree with a DBH of __ inches the dripline is any area within __ feet of the trunk of the tree: 
1-5 inches 5 feet 6-15 inches 12 feet More than 15 inches 20 feet  
(b)  Prior to any construction project, the owner or his agent must install and maintain four-foot high protective fencing around the dripline of any trees situated upon adjacent municipal property. The code enforcement officer shall inspect and approve the fencing and its location prior to the issuance of an erosion control/grading permit. During construction, the code enforcement officer may periodically inspect the fencing to insure that it is property maintained. 
(c)  Any tree planted upon municipal property shall be a minimum of six feet in height and one and one-half inches in diameter (measured six inches from the base) for medium and large trees and four feet in height for small trees. Such trees should be in accordance with the master list shown in section 98-142. 
(d)  No trees, other than those listed as "small trees" shall be planted directly underneath or within ten lateral feet of any overhead utility line; "medium trees" shall be planted ten lateral feet or more from any overhead utility line; and "large trees" shall be planted 20 lateral feet or more from such utility line. Provided, however, that replacement trees may be planted closer to overhead utility lines if deemed appropriate or necessary by the superintendent. 
(e)  Spacing of trees shall be approved by the superintendent in accordance with the following minimum standards: 
Small trees 20 feet apart Medium trees 30 feet apart Large trees 40 feet apart.  
Small trees may be planted between large trees or medium trees as understory trees. The minimum distance shall be planted from existing or proposed curblines and shall be as follows: 
Small trees three feet Medium trees four feet Large trees five feet.  
    The superintendent shall have the authority, at his discretion, to waive or vary the spacing requirements. No tree shall be planted closer than ten feet from any fire hydrant. 
(f)  No tree planting area shall be less than five feet wide and contain less than 25 square feet of pervious area for small trees; 50 square feet for medium trees; and 60 square feet for large trees. The superintendent shall have the authority, at his discretion, to waive or vary the planting area requirements. Trees shall not be planted which would, in the judgement of the superintendent, obstruct visibility at intersections, after consideration of existing or proposed buildings, traffic signals and other traffic control devices. 
(g)  Any person, utility or department excavating underneath the dripline of any tree, after receiving prior written authorization from the code enforcement officer, shall exercise care to undertake the minimum excavation necessary and cause the minimum damage to roots of the tree. Persons, utilities or departments shall, prior to such authorized excavation, consider all alternatives available to avoid damage to the tree and a permit may be denied on the basis that other alternatives are available. As a condition of granting such a permit, the city may require that either the code enforcement officer or superintendent be present on-site during the excavation. No excavation shall be undertaken by any persons, utility or department underneath the dripline of any tree designated as a historic or specimen tree in the comprehensive tree plan, as adopted by the mayor and board of aldermen, without approval of the tree board. 
(h)  Application for a tree permit: 
(1)  A written application for a tree permit shall include the following information: 
a.  The number, species and DBH of trees to be pruned, sprayed, treated, preserved or planted. 
b.  The species, DBH and condition of all trees on public property, within 30 feet of the tree(s) to be pruned, sprayed, treated, preserved or planted. 
(2)  The code enforcement officer may, at his discretion, require that the following information also be provided along with the written application for a tree permit: 
a.  A scale drawing showing existing and/or proposed trees, curbs, sidewalks, pavement, underground utilities and other permanent features. 
b.  Planting details for new trees and information regarding water and maintenance. 
c.  Other information determined by the code enforcement officer to be appropriate or necessary for issuance of a tree permit. 
(Ord. No. 2008-5, § XI, 5-20-2008) 
Sec. 98-138. - Removal of trees on municipal property and preservation of trees on construction projects on municipal property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, utility, or department to remove any tree from municipal property without having first obtained a tree permit therefore. Provided, however, that no such permit shall be required for municipal construction projects approved by the mayor and board of aldermen. Such construction projects shall include a tree planting plan or contain an allowance for tree planting as a part of the construction documents for such project. Prior to commencement of any construction project on municipal property, the superintendent shall review the status of trees on the property, as well as any plans for planting or removal of trees from the property, and shall make recommendations for the retention, preservation, removal and replanting of trees on the property. Four-foot high protective fencing shall be installed and maintained around the dripline of any trees on the construction site which are to be preserved. Such fencing shall be inspected and approved by the superintendent. During construction, the superintendent may visit the site periodically in insure that the protective fencing is property maintained. 
(b)  Applications for permits for tree removal shall be made to the code enforcement officer as specified in this article. The code enforcement officer, upon receipt of a completed tree permit application, shall consult with the superintendent and shall act upon all such applications within 14 days. However, no tree shall be removed if the superintendent decides that such removal is not warranted. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit any person, department or utility from removing any tree in an emergency situation whereby an eminent threat to public health and safety exists. 
(d)  The tree board shall determine whether or not a replacement tree shall be planted for any tree removed, and in instance whereby a replacement tree is required, the tree board shall determine the species of tree(s) to be replanted. 
(e)  All stumps to remain shall be removed to four inches below ground line, covered with topsoil and sodded or planted with appropriate grass, depending upon the season, as directed by the code enforcement officer or superintendent. 
(Ord. No. 2008-5, § XI, 5-20-2008) 
Sec. 98-139. - Exemption of utility companies and city department. 
    Public and private utility companies and department of the city shall be exempt from the permit requirements of this article except in matters pertaining to removal of trees. However, public and private utilities, to the extent practical, are to operate in a manner that favors the preservation of mature trees, including the following of excavation standards set out in this article. Futhermore, all utility companies and departments of the city shall conform to provisions for tree pruning and trimming of the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) ANSI A300-1995. Said standards, and all future amendments thereto, are hereby adopted as part of this article as is expressly contained herein. A copy of said standards shall remain on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2008-5, § XI, 5-20-2008) 
Sec. 98-140. - Trees and shrubs on private property. 
(a)  Any tree situated on private property which overhangs municipal property and becomes a hazard or menace to the public or which interferes with any street light or traffic control device, may be pruned or removed by the city. The code enforcement officer, upon notice from any city department or utility that a privately-owned tree must be removed, shall notify the owner of such tree regarding such removal. Any property owner aggrieved by such determination may appeal such determination to the mayor and board of alderman as provided in this article. Nothing in this section shall prohibit any person, department or utility from removing any privately-owned tree in an emergency situation whereby an eminent threat to public health and safety exists. 
(b)  In the event a tree is removed from private property under the conditions specified above, the city shall, if requested by the property owner, replace such tree with a tree meeting the minimum size requirements of this article and of a mutually agreed upon species. Tree stumps resulting from removal of trees by the city on private property shall be removed by the city as provided by this article. 
(c)  No shrub shall be allowed to grow to such height as may interfere with visibility along or adjacent to the right-of-way line of two intersecting streets for a distance of 50 feet from the point of intersection of such right-of-way lines. Upon receipt of notice that such impairment to visibility exits, a city official shall notify the property owner to prune such shrubs to such height whereby visibility will no longer be impaired. In the event such shrubs are not pruned by the property owner within ten days following such notice, the city may proceed to prune such shrubs as may be required and may assess the corresponding cost of the same to the property owner. 
(Ord. No. 2008-5, § XI, 5-20-2008) 
Sec. 98-141. - Historic or specimen trees. 
(a)  Trees designated as historic or specimen trees in the comprehensive tree plan adopted by the mayor and board of alderman are hereby declared to be protected trees within the city. No person, utility or department shall prune, excavate below the dripline, remove or otherwise disturb such trees without approval of the tree board. Historic or specimen trees situated upon private property may be designated as such by the tree board only after written permission has been obtained from the property owner. Nothing in this article shall authorize the tree board, its members or its agents to enter upon private property for the purpose of examination of any tree without first obtaining permission from the property owner. 
(b)  It is the intent of this article that the designation of "historic" or "specimen" trees by the tree board be extremely limited to only those trees which are, in fact, truly historic to the City of Oxford, Lafayette County or the University of Mississippi or are of such size, species, age or other relevant criteria as to qualify the trees as having extremely high value. 
(Ord. No. 2008-5, § XI, 5-20-2008)

Secs. 98-143-98-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - STREET TRENCHING AND RIGHT-OF-WAY MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 98-151. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, whenever used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Applicant means any owner, contractor, developer, or builder who has submitted an application for a permit to excavate or perform work or construction on, within, or under any street, alley, or public right-of-way. 
    City means the City of Oxford, Mississippi. 
    Director of public works means the director of the public works department, or other person designated by the director of public works. 
    Emergency means the repair of a utility which must be made to restore service, to avoid property damage, or to eliminate danger to the public. 
    Excavation means any opening in the paved or improved surface or subsurface of the public right-of-way. 
    Excavation influence area means the mandatory minimum areas for resurfacing an excavation. 
    Franchise agreement means any agreement validly entered into between the franchisee and a governmental entity. 
    Franchise right means any government or statutory conferred right to engage in a specific business. 
    Installations means any legally authorized type of structure, plant, equipment, or other property installed in the public rights-of-way. 
    Notice means a written notification which is deemed to have been received on the date on which it was faxed or three days after the date on which it was mailed via first class United States Mail, postage pre-paid. 
    Owner means the company or business authorized to construct, repair, or adjust a utility or to perform the work or construction referred to in the application or permit. 
    Pavement means the fully improved roadway surface of the public rights-of-way, designed and constructed to support the movement of vehicular traffic. Pavement typically consists of asphaltic concrete or cement concrete and it includes any subgrade installations. 
    Permit means a permit to perform an excavation, trenching, or cutting across a street or within a right-of-way as it has been approved or may be amended or renewed by the director of public works or his or her designee. 
    Permit application means the prescribed "permit application for the construction, repair, or adjustment of a utility or for work within, on, or under city rights-of-way" or such other application as approved by the director of public works or his or her designee. 
    Person means any natural person, corporation, partnership, or any governmental agency, department, or subdivision of the city, county, or the state, or United States of America. 
    Pothole means a limited excavation used to determine the actual vertical and horizontal location of underground installations. 
    Public rights-of-way or rights-of-way means the paved area across, along, beneath, in, on, over, under, upon, and within the city streets, as they now exist or hereafter will exist and which are or will be under the permitting jurisdiction of the planning department and the public works department. 
    Public utility company means any company, provider, or organization that installs, operates and/or maintains infrastructure for a public service. 
    Resurface or resurfacing means any or all of the following as directed by the director of public works or his or her designee: 
(1)  Any removal and replacement necessary for sub-base repairs using either cement concrete, of full depth base repairs using either cement concrete, or full depth base asphaltic concrete. 
(2)  Coldplaning/milling the gutter-line, and making horizontal header cuts to a minimum depth of one inch, for a minimum of six feet in width, or if required by the city engineer/director of public works, cold planing/milling of the entire street width. 
(3)  Replacement of any damaged traffic signal detection loops. 
(4)  Placement of pavement reinforcing fabrics, if required by the director of public works or his or her designee.
