Sec. 114-40. - Sewer connection fee. 
(a)  Inside city limits: A fee of $400.00 for each dwelling unit shall be paid by the applicant for sewer service from the city for the connection of his premises with the city's sanitary sewer system. In the event a new manhole or any other than normal operating procedure is required, as determined by the city engineer, to connect any applicant's premises into the city's sewer system the connection fee shall be the total direct cost of labor and materials to install such manhole or undertake such other procedure, as determined by the city engineer. 
(b)  Outside city limits: A fee of $800.00 for each dwelling unit shall be paid by the applicant for sewer service from the city for the connection of his premises with the city's sanitary sewer system, regardless of the distance of the premises from the city limits. In the event a new manhole or any other than normal operating procedure is required, as determined by the city engineer, to connect any applicant's premises into the city's sewer system the connection fee shall be the total direct cost of labor and materials to install such manhole or undertake such other procedure, as determined by the city engineer. 
(Code 1968, § 31-21; Ord. No. 1970-7, § 2, 8-18-1970; Ord. No. 1974-7, § 2, 10-1-1974; Ord. No. 1981-20, § 2, 9-1-1981; Ord. No. 1984-5, § 3, 6-5-1984; Ord. No. 1999-13, § 2, 11-2-1999; Ord. No. 2005-21, § I, 10-18-2005; Ord. No. 2008-5, § X, 5-20-2008; Ord. No. 2010-16, § 4, 12-21-2010) 
Sec. 114-41. - Water rates. 
(a)  Inside city limits. Inside the city limits the monthly water rate shall be $3.55 per 1,000 gallons over 2,000 gallons. The minimum charge shall be $7.10 per month per occupied residential unit connected to the meter, unless otherwise provided for by this Code. The minimum charge for business, commercial or industrial units shall be $7.10 per month for each meter. 
(b)  Outside city limits. Consumers residing outside the city limits using water furnished by the city shall pay the monthly rate of $4.87 per 1,000 gallons over 2,000 gallons. The minimum charge shall be $9.74 per month. 
(c)  Non-metered customers. For customers on a water system which is either (1) not metered or (2) metered but which meter readings are not accessible to the city, a flat rate of $24.30 per month shall be charged for water. The city may install meters and charge these customers metered rates when feasible. 
(d)  Bell Utilities service areas. In addition to the rates above, water system customers lying outside the city limits, but within the areas described in and which were held by Bell Utilities of Mississippi, LLC's MPSC-Lafayette County Certificates of Public Convenience and Necessity, shall be charged one additional monthly fee per water utility bill as follows: Water customers with monthly water usage metered at under 3,000 gallons shall be charged a $4.00 monthly fee. Water customers with a monthly water usage metered at 3,000 gallons and above shall be charged a $6.00 monthly fee. Non-metered customers shall be charged a $6.00 monthly fee. The charge reflects the costs of maintenance, including replacement of the water works and retirement of existing debt related to the systems. 
(e)  Annual review. The city will annually review all water rates as part of the yearly budget process. 
(Code 1968, § 31-22; Ord. No. 1970-7, § 3, 8-18-1970; Ord. No. 1974-7, § 3, 10-1-1974; Ord. No. 1980-14, § 1, 9-15-1980; Ord. No. 1981-20, § 3, 9-1-1981; Ord. No. 1986-6, § 1, 5-8-1986; Ord. No. 1989-16, § 1, 9-5-1989; Ord. No. 1990-8, § 1, 8-10-1990; Ord. No. 1997-10, § 1, 9-2-1997; Ord. No. 2005-18, § I, 10-18-2005; Ord. No. 2006-5, § 1, 5-2-2006; Ord. No. 2010-9, § 1, 9-21-2010; Ord. No. 2010-15, § 1, 12-21-2010; Ord. No. 2013-21, § 1, 12-17-2013) 
Sec. 114-42. - Water rate billing. 
(a)  All water rates are subject to applicable state sales tax. 
(b)  Where one or more occupancy or business or any combination thereof is connected to one water meter, billing must be accepted by the owner of the property. 
(Code 1968, § 31-23; Ord. No. 1970-7, § 4, 8-18-1970; Ord. No. 1974-7, § 4, 10-1-1974) 
Sec. 114-43. - User charge. 
(a)  All users pay user charges. The user charge shall be the charge levied on all users including, but not limited to, persons, firms, corporations or governmental entities that discharge, cause or permit the discharge of sewage into the public sewage works. 
(b)  Cost of operation and maintenance. The user charge shall reflect the costs of operation and maintenance (including replacement) of the public sewage works, retirement of existing debt included herein, and repayment of any state revolving fund loans. In addition, each user shall be notified at least annually of the rate and portion of the user charges or ad valorem taxes attributable to operation, maintenance and simple replacement of the treatment system. 
(c)  Proportionate share of costs. Each user shall pay its proportionate share of operation and maintenance (including replacement) costs based on volume flow. 
(d)  Review of user charges. 
(1)  The mayor and board of aldermen shall review not less often than every two years the sewage contributions of users, the total costs of operation and maintenance (including replacement) of the sewage works, and the user charge system. 
(2)  The mayor and board of aldermen shall revise the user charge, if necessary, to accomplish the following: 
a.  Maintain the proportionate distribution of operation and maintenance cost among users as provided herein. 
b.  Generate sufficient revenue to pay the total operation and maintenance costs necessary for the proper operation and maintenance (including replacement) of the sewage works, retirement of existing debt included herein, and repayment of any state revolving fund loans. 
(Code 1968, § 31-23.1; Ord. No. 1991-4, § 1, 4-16-1991; Ord. No. 1991-7, § 1, 6-4-1991) 
Sec. 114-44. - Sewer rates. 
(a)  Inside city limits. Inside the city limits, the monthly volumetric charge for sanitary sewer service shall be $4.72 per 1,000 gallons over 2,000 gallons. The minimum monthly charge shall be $9.44. 
(b)  Outside city limits. Outside the city limits, the monthly volumetric charge for sanitary sewer service shall be $5.47 per 1,000 gallons over 2,000. The minimum monthly charge shall be $10.94. 
(c)  Non-metered customers. For customers on a sewer system which is either (1) not metered or (2) metered but which meter readings are not accessible to the city, a flat rate of $27.35 per month shall be charged for sewer. The city may install meters and charge these customers metered rates when feasible. 
(d)  Bell Utilities service areas. In addition to the rates above, sewer customers lying outside the city limits, but within the areas described in and which were held by Bell Utilities of Mississippi, LLC's MPSC-Lafayette County Certificates of Public Convenience and Necessity, shall be charged one additional $6.00 fee monthly per sewer utility bill. The charge reflects the costs of maintenance, including replacement of the sewer works and retirement of existing debt related to the systems. 
(e)  Review of sewer rates. The city will annually review sewer rates as part of the yearly budget process. 
(Code 1968, § 31-24; Ord. No. 1977-3, § 1, 2-1-1977; Ord. No. 1980-14, § 1, 9-15-1980; Ord. No. 1981-20, § 4, 9-1-1981; Ord. No. 1989-16, § 1, 9-5-1989; Ord. No. 1990-8, § 2, 8-10-1990; Ord. No. 1992-4, § 1, 5-5-1992; Ord. No. 1997-10, § 2, 9-2-1997; Ord. No. 2002-10, § 1, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 2005-19, § I, 10-18-2005; Ord. No. 2006-5, § 2, 5-2-2006; Ord. No. 2010-9, § 2, 9-21-2010; Ord. No. 2010-15, § 2, 12-21-2010; Ord. No. 2013-21, § 2, 12-17-2013) 
Sec. 114-45. - Electricity rates-Residential rate, Schedule RS. 
(a)  Standard rate. All rates that are marked as standard rate shall be those rates in effect for that type of service at the time of billing as approved by the board of aldermen and the TVA. This shall include any applicable fuel cost adjustment as may be determined by the TVA. 
(b)  Inspection of rates. All rates shall be posted at the city electric department office for inspection during regular business hours. 
(1)  Availability. 
a.  Single-family private dwellings. This rate shall apply only to electric service in a single-family private dwelling and its appurtenances (if served through the same meter), the major use of which is for lighting and household appliances, for the personal comfort and convenience of those residing therein. 
b.  Private dwellings where occasional business is conducted. Private dwellings in which space is occasionally used for the conduct of business by a person residing therein will be served under this rate. 
c.  Dwelling where conduct of regular business. Where a portion of a dwelling is used regularly for the conduct of business: 
1.  The electricity consumed in the portion so used will be separately metered and billed under the general power rate (section 114-47); 
2.  If separate circuits are not provided by the customer, service to the entire premises shall be billed under the general power rate (section 114-47). 
d.  Other multi-dwelling users. This rate shall not apply to service to institutions such as clubs, fraternities, orphanages or nursing homes, recognized roominghouses or boardinghouses, or the space in an apartment or other residential building primarily devoted to use as an office or studio for professional or other gainful purposes. 
(2)  Character of service. Alternating current, single-phase 60 hertz. Voltage supplied will be at the discretion of the electric department and will be determined by the voltage available from distribution lines in the vicinity and/or other conditions. 
(3)  Rate. 
Customer charge, per 
month ..... Standard rate 
Energy Charge: 
First 2,000 kwh per month, per kwh ..... Standard rate 
Additional kwh per month, per kwh ..... Standard rate 
(4)  Adjustment. The base energy charge shall be increased or decreased in accordance with the current adjustment addendum published by the Tennessee Valley Authority. 
(5)  Minimum monthly bill. The base customer charge constitutes the minimum monthly bill for all customers served under this rate schedule except those customers for which a higher minimum monthly bill is required under the city electric department's standard policy because of special circumstances affecting the cost of rendering service. 
(6)  Payment. Bills under this rate schedule will be rendered monthly. Any amount of the bill unpaid after the due date specified on the bill may be subject to additional charges under the city electric department's standard policy. 
(7)  Single-point delivery. The above rates and charges are based upon the supply of service through a single delivery and metering point and at a single voltage. Separate supply for the same customer at other points of consumption or at different voltages shall be separately metered and billed. 
(8)  Rules and regulations. Service under this rate schedule is subject to rules and regulations of the electric department. 
(Code 1968, § 31-25; Ord. No. 1970-10, § 1, 10-6-1970; Ord. No. 1979-14, § 1, 11-20-1979; Ord. No. 1991-19, § 1, 9-3-1991; Ord. No. 2001-14, § 1, 10-16-2001; Ord. No. 2006-16, § I(31-25), 9-19-2006) 
Sec. 114-46. - Same-General power rate, Schedule GSA. 
(a)  All rates that are marked as standard rate shall be those rates in effect for that type of service at the time of billing as approved by the board of aldermen and the TVA. This shall include any applicable "fuel cost adjustment" as may be determined by the TVA. 
(b)  All rates shall be posted at the city electric department office for inspection during regular business hours. 
(1)  Availability. This rate shall apply to the firm power requirements for electric service to commercial, industrial, and governmental customers; institutional customers including, without limitation, churches, clubs, fraternities, orphanages, nursing homes, roominghouses and boardinghouses, and like customers; and other customers except those to whom service is available under the residential (section 114-45) or outdoor lighting (section 114-48) rate schedule. 
(2)  Character of service. Alternating current, single or three-phase, 60 hertz. Power sold under this rate schedule will be delivered at a voltage available in the vicinity or agreed to by the electric department. 
(3)  Rate. 
a.  GSA-1. If the customer's contract demand is 50 kilowatts or less or if the customer's highest billing demand during the latest 12-month period is not more than 50 kilowatts and the customer's monthly energy takings for any month during such period do not exceed 15,000 kilowatt hours: 
1.  Customer charge per delivery point per month ..... Standard 
rate. 
2.  Energy charge per kwh per month ..... Standard 
rate. 
b.  GSA-2. If the customer's contract demand is 51 kilowatts to 1,000 kilowatts or if the customer's highest billing demand during the latest 12-month period is greater than 50 kilowatts but not more than 1,000 kilowatts, or if the customer's billing demand is less than 50 kilowatts and its energy takings for any month during such period exceed 15,000 kilowatt hours: 
1.  Customer charge per delivery point per month ..... Standard 
rate. 
2.  Demand charge: 
i.  First 50 kw of billing demand, no 
demand charge ..... Standard 
rate. 
ii.  All kw pf demand over 50 kw per month, per kw ..... Standard 
rate. 
3.  Energy charge: 
i.  First 15,000 kwh per month, per kwh ..... Standard 
rate. 
ii.  Additional kwh per month, per kwh ..... Standard 
rate. 
c.  GSA-3. If the customer's contract demand is 1,001 kilowatts to 5,000 kilowatts or if the customer's highest billing demand during the latest 12-month period is greater than 1,001 kilowatts: 
1.  Customer charge per delivery point per month ..... Standard 
rate. 
2.  Demand charge: 
i.  First 1,000 kw per month, per kw ..... Standard 
rate. 
ii.  Additional kw per month, per kw ..... Standard 
rate. 
3.  Energy charge: 
All kwh ..... Standard 
rate. 
(4)  Adjustment. The base demand and energy charges shall be increased or decreased in accordance with the current adjustment addendum published by the Tennessee Valley Authority. 
(5)  Minimum bill . The monthly bill under subsections (b)(3)a, (b)(3)b, and (b)(3)c of this section shall not be less than the higher of: 
a.  The sum of the base customer charge, the base demand charge, as adjusted, applied to 30 percent of the higher of the currently effective contract demand of the highest demand established during the preceding 12 months, and the base energy charge, as adjusted, applied, to the customer's energy takings; or 
b.  The sum of the base customer charges and 20 percent of the portion of the base demand charges, as adjusted, applicable to the second block of billing demand, multiplied by the higher of the customer's currently effective contract demand of its highest billing demand established during the preceding 12 months. 
(6)  Seasonal service. Customers who contract for service on a seasonal basis shall be limited to 2,500 kilowatts and shall pay the above charges, as adjusted, plus an additional seasonal use charge at standard rate. Consistent with the city electric department's standard policy, the customer may arrange for seasonal testing of equipment during off-peak hours. 
For such customers, the minimum bill provided for above shall not apply. The city electric department may require additional charges to provide recovery of costs for customer-specific distribution facilities. 
(7)  Contract requirement. 
a.  The city electric department may require contracts for all service provided under this rate schedule if it is deemed necessary by the electric department to protect the interest of the rate payers. 
b.  Customers whose demand requirements exceed 50 kilowatts may be required to execute contracts and if so required, such contracts will be for an initial term of at least one year. The customer shall contract for its maximum requirements, which shall not exceed the amount of power capable of being used by the customer, and the city electric department will not be obligated to supply power in a greater amount at any time than the customer's currently effective contract demand. 
c.  If the customer uses any power other than that supplied by the city electric department under this rate schedule, the contract may include other special provisions. 
d.  The rate schedule in any power contract will be subject to adjustment, modification, change or replacement from time to time as provided under the power contract between the city electric department and the Tennessee Valley Authority. 
(8)  Determination of demand. The city electric department shall measure the demands in kilowatts of all customers having loads in excess of 50 kilowatts. Under this rate schedule, the demand for any month shall be the higher of the highest average during any 30 consecutive minute period of the month of the load measured in kilowatts, 85 percent of the load in kva, and such amount shall be used as the billing demand, except that the billing demand for any month shall in no case be less than 30 percent of the higher of the currently effective contract demand of the highest billing demand established during the preceding 12 months. 
(9)  Payment. Billing under this rate schedule will be rendered monthly. Any amount of the bill unpaid after the due date specified on the bill may be subject to additional charges under the city electric department's standard policy. 
(10)  Single-point delivery. The charges under this rate schedule are based upon the supply of service through a single delivery and metering point and at a single voltage. If service is supplied to the same customer through more than one point of delivery or at different voltages, the supply of service at each delivery and metering point and at each different voltage shall be separately metered and billed. 
(11)  Rules and regulations. Service is subject to rules and regulations of the electric department. 
(Code 1968, § 31-26A; Ord. No. 2001-14, § 2, 10-16-2001; Ord. No. 2006-16, § I(31-26A), 9-19-2006) 
Sec. 114-47. - Same-General power rate, Schedule GSB. 
(a)  All rates that are marked as standard rate shall be those rates in effect for that type of service at the time of billing as approved by the board of aldermen and the TVA. This shall include any applicable fuel cost adjustment as may be determined by the TVA. 
(b)  All rates shall be posted at the city electric department office for inspection during regular business hours. 
(1)  Availability. This rate shall apply to the firm electric power requirements where a customer's currently effective contract demand is greater than 5,000 kilowatts but not more than 15,000 kilowatts. 
(2)  Character of service. Alternating current, single- or three-phase 60 hertz. Power shall be delivered at a transmission voltage of 161 kv or, if such transmission voltage is not available, at the highest voltage available in the vicinity, unless at the city electric department's request, a lower standard voltage is agreed upon. 
(3)  Rate. 
a.  Customer charge: Per delivery point per 
month ..... Standard 
rate. 
b.  Demand charge: 
1.  Per kw billing demand per 
month ..... Standard 
rate. 
2.  Plus an additional, 
per kw per month 
for each kw, if any, 
of the amount by 
which the customer's 
billing demand 
exceeds its contract demand ..... Standard 
rate. 
c.  Energy charge: 
1.  Per kwh for up to 620 hours use of metered demand per month ..... Standard 
rate. 
2.  All additional kwh per month, per kwh ..... Standard 
rate. 
(4)  Adjustment . The base demand and energy charges shall be increased or decreased in accordance with the current adjustment addendum published by the Tennessee Valley Authority. 
(5)  Facilities rental charge. There shall be no facilities rental charge under this rate schedule for delivery at bulk transmission voltage levels of 161 kv or higher. For delivery at less than 161 kv, there shall be added to the customer's bill a facilities rental charge. This charge shall be at standard rate. Such charge shall be applied to the higher of: 
a.  The highest billing demand established during the latest 12 consecutive month period; or 
b.  The customer's currently effective contract demand; and shall be in addition to all other charges under this rate schedule, including minimum bill charges. 
(6)  Reactive demand charges. If the reactive demand (in kvar) is lagging during the 30 consecutive minute period beginning or ending on a clock hour of the month in which the customer's highest metered demand occurs, there shall be added to the customer's bill a reactive charge at standard rate kvar of the amount, if any, by which the reactive demand exceeds 33 percent of such metered demand. If the reactive demand (in kvar) is leading during the 30-consecutive-minute period beginning or ending on a clock hour of the month in which the customer's lowest metered demand (excluding any metered demands which are less than 25 percent of the highest metered demand) occurs, there shall be added to the customer's bill a reactive charge at standard rate per kvar of the amount of reactive demand. Such charges shall be in addition to all other charges under this rate schedule, including minimum bill charges. 
(7)  Determination of demand. The city electric department shall meter the demands in kilowatts of all customers served under this rate schedule. The metered demand for any month shall be the highest average during any 30-consecutive-minute period beginning or ending on a clock hour of the month of the load metered in kilowatts, and such amount shall be used as the billing demand, except that the billing demand for any month shall in no case be less than the sum of: 
a.  Thirty percent of the first 5,000 kilowatts; and 
b.  Forty percent of any kilowatts in excess of 5,000 kilowatts of the higher of the currently effective contract demand or the highest billing demand established during the preceding 12 months. 
(8)  Minimum bill. The monthly bill under this rate schedule, excluding any facilities rental charges and any reactive charges, shall not be less than the sum of: 
a.  The base customer charge; 
b.  The base demand charge, as adjusted (but excluding the additional portion thereof applicable to excess of billing demand over contract demand) applied to the customer's billing demand; and 
c.  The base energy charge, as adjusted, applied to the customer's energy takings. 
The city electric department may require minimum bills higher than those stated in this subsection (8). 
(9)  Contract requirement. 
a.  The city electric department shall require contracts for all service provided under this rate schedule. 
b.  The contract shall be for an initial term of at least five years and any renewals or extensions of the initial contract shall be for a term of at least one year, after ten years of service, any such contract for the renewal or extension of service may provide for termination upon not less that four months' notice. 
c.  The customer shall contract for its maximum requirements, which shall not exceed the amount of power capable of being used by the customer, and the city electric department shall not be obligated to supply power in a greater amount at any time than the customer's currently effective contract demand. If the customer uses any power other than that supplied by the city electric department under this rate schedule, the contract may include other special provisions. 
d.  The rate schedule in any power contract shall be subject to adjustment, modification, change, or replacement from time to time as provided under the power contract between the city electric department and the the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). 
(10)  Payment. Bills under this rate schedule will be rendered monthly. Any amount of the bill unpaid after the due date specified on bill may be subject to additional charges under the city electric department's standard policy. 
(11)  Single-point delivery. The charges under this rate schedule are based upon the supply of service through a single delivery and metering point, and at a single voltage. If service is supplied to the same customer through more than one point of delivery or at different voltages, the supply of service at each delivery and metering point and at each different voltage shall be separately metered and billed. 
(12)  Rules and regulations . Service is subject to rules and regulations of the electric department. 
(Code 1968, § 31-26B; Ord. No. 2001-14, § 2, 10-16-2001; Ord. No. 2006-16, § I(31-26B), 9-19-2006) 
Sec. 114-48. - Same-Outdoor lighting rate, Schedule LP. 
(a)  Standard rates. All rates that are marked as standard rate shall be those rates in effect for that type of service at the time of billing as approved by the board of aldermen and the TVA. This shall include any applicable fuel cost adjustment as may be determined by the TVA. 
(b)  Posted rates not standard. All rates shall be posted at the city electric department office for inspection during regular business hours. 
(1)  Availability. Available for service to street and park lighting systems, traffic signal systems, athletic field lighting installations, and outdoor lighting for individual customers. Service under this schedule is for a term of not less than one year. 
(2)  Payment. Bills under this rate schedule will be rendered monthly. Any amount of the bill unpaid after the due date specified on the bill may be subject to additional charges under the city electric department's standard policy. 
(3)  Adjustment . The energy charge of this rate schedule shall be increased or decreased in accordance with the current adjustment addendum published by the Tennessee Valley Authority. 
(4)  Rates. 
a.  Rates for street and park lighting, signal systems and athletic field lighting installation. 
1.  Energy charge . Energy charge per month per kilowatt hours is the standard rate. 
2.  Facility charge. The annual facility charge shall be 16 percent of the installed cost to the city electric department of the facilities devoted to street and park lighting service specified in the part. Such installed cost shall be recomputed on July 1 of each year or more often if substantial changes in the facilities are made. Each month one-twelfth of the then-total annual facility charge shall be billed to the customer. If any part of the facilities has not been provided at the electric system's expense or if the installed cost of any portion thereof is reflected on the books of another municipality or agency or department, the annual facility charge shall be adjusted to reflect properly the remaining cost to be borne by the electric system. 
3.  Traffic systems and athletic fields not maintained by the city. Traffic signal systems and athletic field lighting installations shall be provided, owned, and maintained by and at the expense of the customer, except as the city electric department may agree otherwise in accordance with the provision of subsection (b)(4)a.4 of this section. The facilities necessary to provide service to such systems and installations shall be provided by and at the expense of the electric department, and the annual facility charge provided for in subsection (4)a.2. of this section shall apply to the installed cost of such facilities. 
4.  Traffic systems and athletic field lighting owned and maintained by the city. When so authorized by policy duly adopted by the board of aldermen of the city, traffic signal systems and athletic field lighting installations may be provided, owned and maintained by the city electric department for the customer's benefit. In such cases, the city electric department may require reimbursement from the customer for a portion of the initial installed cost of any such system or installation and shall require payment by the customer of a facility charge sufficient to cover all the electric department's costs (except reimbursed costs), including appropriate overheads, of providing, owning, and maintaining such system or installation; provided that for athletic field lighting installations, such facility charge shall in no case be less than 12 percent per year of such costs. Such facility charge shall be in addition to the annual facility charge on the facilities necessary to provide for in this subsection. Replacement of lamps and related glassware for traffic signal systems and athletic field lighting installations provided under this subsection (b)(4)a.4 shall be paid for under the provisions of subsection (b)(4)a.6 of this section. 
5.  Customer charge. Traffic signal systems and athletic field lighting installations. The electric department will apply a uniform monthly customer charge at standard rate for service to each traffic signal system or athletic field lighting installation. 
6.  Replacement of lamps and related glassware. Street and park lighting. The city electric department will bill the customer monthly for one-twelfth of the amount by which the electric department's cost of materials, including appropriate storeroom expense, exceeds the product of $0.003 multiplied by the number of kilowatt hours used for street and park lighting during the fiscal year immediately preceding the fiscal year in which such month occurs. 
7.  Metering. For any billing month or part of such month in which the energy is not metered, for which a meter reading is found to be in error or a meter is found to have failed, the energy for billing purposes for that billing month or part of such month shall be computed form the rated capacity of the lamps (including ballast) plus five percent of such capacity to reflect secondary circuit losses, multiplied by the number of hours of use. 
8.  Revenue and cost review. The electric department's costs of providing service under subsection (b)(4)a of this section are subject to review at any time and from time to time to determine if the city electric department's revenues from the charges being applied are sufficient to cover its costs. (Such costs, including applicable overheads, include but are not limited to, those incurred in the operation and maintenance of the systems provided and those resulting from depreciation and payments for taxes, tax equivalents, and interest.) If any such review discloses that revenues are either less or more than sufficient to cover said costs, the city electric department will revise the facility charges provided for in this section so that revenues will be sufficient to cover said costs. Any such revision of the annual facility charge provided for in subsection (4)a.2 of this section shall be by agreement between the electric department and the Tennessee Valley Authority. 
b.  Charges for outdoor lighting for individual customers.
